title: locals tape street sign named colston bristol
story: Blue tape has been plastered over the Colston Road sign in Bristol and a suggestion box has been installed below asking for new name ideas.Residents said they wanted a name that reflected the erse and inclusive feel of the area.Colston Road resident Dan Stone said: Who wants to live in a street named after a slave trader This is a multicultural area, we like that about it. It [the slave trade] is not something we want to celebrate.Businessman Abdul Malik said: Bristol is a city of inclusion - a city that provides sanctuary for refugees and asylum seekers.[But] when you drive around Bristol, its quite embarrassing to see places like Blackboy Hill and Whiteladies Road, and Colston being celebrated.Times have changed, and what was seen to be acceptable and normal at one time cant be seen to be acceptable at this time.Easton is erse and inclusive and I think it makes sense to rename that particular road to something that encapsulates that, rather than Mr Colston.Meanwhile a -year-old portrait of Colston was today removed from the Lord Mayors parlour at Bristols City Hall.The toppling of the statue of Colston in Bristol on Sunday has led to demands for other historic monuments to be removed.The statue was pulled down amid worldwide protests triggered by the death of George Floyd. It was fetched from Bristol harbour this morning. A website called topple the racists has compiled a list of around  statues and other memorials across the UK it argues should be taken down, because they celebrate slavery and racism.This includes th-century slave owner Sir Thomas Picton, th-century colonialist trader Robert Clive and th-century merchant Elihu Yale who had links to the slave trade.Campaigners have also challenged memorials to Sir Robert Peel, founder of the Met Police in London and former prime minister William Gladstone.The statue of slave owner Robert Milligan was removed from West India Quay in Londons Docklands on Tuesday night.London Mayor Sadiq Khan has also announced a new commission to review the capitals landmarks.In Oxford, hundreds gathered on Tuesday evening to demand the fall of a statue of Victorian imperialist Cecil Rhodes.In Edinburgh, a petition has been launched to remove the statue of slave owner Henry Dundas in St Andrew Square and for streets bearing his name to be renamed.Police officers with full riot gear will be on standby this weekend kitted up and ready to go amid fears of potential clashes between far-right extremists and anti-racism activists. Busloads of fans attached to firms at ious football clubs are planning to travel hundreds of miles to defend monuments after a number were vandalised during the Black Lives Matter demos.There are fears hundreds are planning to attend a patriotic unity event at Churchills statue in Westminster on Saturday morning.The Democratic Football Lads Alliance, a network founded in  that claims to oppose terrorism and conserve British traditions, has told members to defend statues and war memorials.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: captain cook was a genuine working class hero and his statues should stay says his hometowns mayor
story: A campaign called Topple the Racists has argued that memorials for Captain Cook should be taken down as he was a colonialist who murdered Maori people while discovering New Zealand in the th century.The calls come as Black Lives Matter protesters target statues across the UK.In Bristol, a statue of slave trader Edward Colson was torn from its plinth and thrown into the harbour on Sunday, while growing pressure led to a memorial to Robert Milligan in London being removed on Tuesday.Topple the Racists activists have drawn up a list of  offensive statues they want gone - including Captain Cook.Middlesbrough mayor Andy Preston said the Teesside area was proud of Captain Cook and that his monuments in the town as well as in Great Ayton, Whitby and London should stay standing.Cook was probably the greatest ever and certainly the most successful Teessider in history and the vast majority of us are rightly proud of his achievements on his great voyages of discovery, he told the Northern Echo.Cook was a genuine, working-class hero who rose from being a labourers son to the most celebrated man in Europe.Of course. they were very dferent times and Im sure that a modern day Captain Cook would not act in the way that he did back then, when values, standards and beliefs were very dferent to modern thinking.He was responsible for the first European contact with the east coast of Australia and Hawaii, and he also was the first to sail all the way around New Zealand.Cooks legacy as a great seafarer and explorer has been questioned due to claims of violence and brutality.In Australia, Aboriginal people claim Cooks arrival at Botany Bay in Sydney in  was not peaceful and that he shot and killed indigenous people before reaching land. Activists believe Cooks arrival was an invasion.Similarly in New Zealand, those against Cook claim he and his crew were responsible for killing the native Maori people and spreading disease after they arrived in .Cook was killed in Hawaii in .Mr Preston called on other politicians to publicly support retaining Captain Cooks statues.A primary school, road and hospital are named after Cook in Middlesbrough.Whitby MP Robert Goodwill also advocated for keeping Captain Cooks statues, saying the monument of a young Cook in his town would be only removed over my dead body.This is a ridiculous suggestion. If they decide to remove the Great Ayton statue then I am sure we would find a second location in Whitby for it, he said.Great Ayton parish council chairman Ron Kirk argued that the statue of Captain Cook in his village should stay.Cook, for his day, was probably well-advanced, he said.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leave seat up four new toilet rules everyone needs covid lockdown eases
story: And with support bubbles coming into effect on Saturday even more people will be looking forward to spending time outside of their own homes.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut its likely that an afternoon tipple outdoors might leave visitors needing to go to the loo. So how can you use their toilet facilities safely and what are the rulesyou get caught short when youre out and about We spoke to some experts to find out how you can make the most of the Governments new relaxed rules and keep safe...For years we have been told its only polite to put the toilet seat down when we have finished our business.James Milnes, managing director at Zoonos, said leaving the seat up is more hygiene friendly.Leave the lid of the loo seat up to reduce the number of people needing to touch it to lt the seat up and down. To be courteous to other guests, clean the loo seat with an antibacterial wipe after use.Washing your hands for  seconds, socially distancing, not trying each others drinks, are all things we should be doing to protect ourselves from the virus.But some people may be more liberal than others when it comes to hygiene and what they think is acceptable.If you are having people over to your house Dr Lisa Ackerley, the Hygiene Doctor, suggests making it clear to guests what you expect from them before they arrive.She told The Sun: With less than half of the population practising surface hygiene within their homes according to new research from Unilever, we all need to remember the importance of targeted hygiene in and out of our homes. With this in mind, when visiting the toilets at our friends’ houses, take care to follow hygiene advice.For those who are hosting guests, it’s not a bad idea to have a chat before your guests come about how you are going to manage visits to the toilet during their visit.Of course, youll never be using the toilet at the same time as someone , but its important that on your way there you keep two metres apart from others.Its also vital not to congregate in dferent rooms in the house and make sure the route is clear for the other person to pass.Dr Marybeth Sexton, an infectious diseases expert at Emory University School of Medicine, said letting someone  use your bathroom is safer than you might think - as long as you take some precautions.If someone goes into the house to use the restroom, let them go in alone.Dr Lisa said you should also wait until the coast is clear before trying to get to the bathroom, making sure there is a clear pathway for you.Just because you look after your personal hygiene, it doesnt mean that others do the same.If youre at someone s house then make sure you take your own hand sanitiser just to be on the safe side.Once youve washed your hands make sure you dry them properly.Dr Lisa said: “Just before entering the bathroom, use hand sanitiserso that your hands are clean when you touch door handles and the flush. Once inside the bathroom and the door is closed, wash your hands for  seconds using soap and water before going to the loo. And then wash them again after going to the loo.If youre hosting its important to remind your guests to wash their hands.Dr Sexton told the LA Times: When they’re done, it’s critically important that they wash their hands really well.Its also important to make sure all the guests are not using the same hand towel and perhaps you could provide paper towels or kitchen towels for them to dry their hands with.Moist or wet hands can breed germs so make sure you dry them properly before leaving the bathroom.Dr Lisa said that you should also clean surfaces once you have used them so the next person after you can go to the loo safely.If your host has provided disinfectant, then use it on any surfaces you may have touched. Once you are done, go straight back outside, don’t be tempted to linger.Once outside use a hand sanitiser again, particularlyyou have touched anything . ”When it comes to the host, she said: It is very important that you regularly disinfect frequently touched surfaces in the bathroom – such as bathroom taps, loo roll holder and toilet handles or flush button - before your guests arrive. Then disinfect again, before and after someone has used it, using products that are known to kill SARS-CoV- such as Domestos Thick Bleachand C Antibacterial Spray that have recently been tested in a lab to confirm this.”With most facilities closed and people free to exercise to their hearts content, at some point someone is going to need to go the loo.Local councils have closed public toilets and some parks such as Clissold Park in Stoke Newington, London, have signs all around warning the park is not a toilet, go homeyou need to go.If you pee outside you could risk being prosecuted for public indecency.If you have friends in the local area then you could text or call and ask to use their toilet. Make sure on days out you take wipes and hand sanitiser with you just in case.Data from charity Water Aid has revealed that more than one in six women who are menstruating worry about where they can go to the toilet when they are on their period with the majority of facilities being closed.Its clear that this is a problem many people are dealing with and sales of the Sheewee, a device that lets women urinate without exposing themselves,has seen an increase of sales of up to  per cent during the lockdown.Health researcher Valentina Milanova said there are also a whole host of other issues for women.Assuming that people with periods can spend unlimited time outside, without access to public toilets, is unrealistic. If someone is on their period or unexpectedly starts their period while outdoors, then complications will arise as they are unable to use or change sanitary products. This could result in health issues for the user, as sanitary products such as tampons require regular changes or washes. For women on their period who dont have access to a toilet experts said it may be time to time a menstrual cup that doesnt need to be changed for  hours.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boy lost mountain two days survived autism psychologist
story: William Callaghan went missing on Monday while hiking with his family on Mount Disappointment in Victoria, Australia.The disappearance prompted urgent fears for Williams safety, with nighttime temperatures in the area currently below freezing. A manhunt involving more than  people was launched, and yesterday the teen was found alive and well.Mum Penny said her son probably thought the whole incident was a bit of an adventure, while a child psychologist has said it could be his condition that helped him survive. Speaking to news.au, Professor Robyn Young of Flinders University said: “His autism meant he was at risk because he wasn’t responding by name and he was upset by helicopters flying overhead.But at the same time there were a number of things that were protecting him.“Much of them relate to hypersensitivity and hyposensitivity – basically they have a high pain threshold.“We’re not surethey don’t feel it or don’t respond to it but I’ve seen kids that have walked around with broken bones.”She added that William probably didnt feel the cold as much as another child would have. As part of the hunt, emergency responders played the theme tune from Thomas the Tank Engine, Williams favourite TV show, over a PA system. He was eventually found by volunteer Ben Gibbs almost  hours after last being seen.I was wandering through the bush, and it was quite thick so I was breaking my way through it, said Gibbs. And then he was just about  meters from me standing there, just really angelic.Speaking to local media shortly after the discovery, Penny Callaghan said: Im obviously immensely relieved. I am really overwhelmed. Hes well as can be expected in the circumstances.She said today that William slept well last night and is in good spirits. story: Professor Tim Spector, who is running the COVID Symptom Tracker, said that between one in ten and one in five people reporting symptoms on the app were mentioning new, mysterious rashes.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAnd the scientist, from Kings College London, is now urging doctors to be suspicious of the potential sign of deadly Covid-. Professor Spector, of King’s College London, said there was the possibility that a rash might be the only symptom displayed by children who had contracted Covid-.He told the " rel"nofollow noreferrer noopener"Evening Standard: “It’s looking like it is predictive of having a positive [coronavirus] test and GPs are unaware of it, so they are sending people away, or NHS  is not recognising it as a possible symptom.“It’s usually in combination [with other symptoms] but it can come on at dferent times — sometimes after the other symptoms. It can come two weeks after the other symptoms, or two weeks before - it’s just being missed because the public is unaware of it and doctors are unaware of it.Prof Spector pointed out that rashes had been highlighted in early cases of Covid- from China and Europe, but there had not been any published studies so far. He cautioned people to be vigilant, adding: It can just last for a day and disappear...other people get it for a long time.”Developed by researchers at Kings College London and company ZOE, the COVID Symptom Tracker has been helping to predict the scale of the coronavirus outbreak in the UK.Anyone - including healthy people, those who think they might have Covid- and those who have been diagnosed with the virus - can download the app and fill out some forms which describe their health and ask about possible coronavirus symptoms.It has been used by almost four million people in the UK.Prof Spectors symptom tracker app was the first to highlight the loss of taste and smell as Covid- symptoms - and these were eventually added to the official NHS list last month.And he believes his team have also detected the new symptom of skin rashes several weeks before Public Health England do anything about it. A mum-of-one revealed earlier today that she suffered terrying mystery rashes for months before testing positive for Covid-. Sarah Churchill, , developed incredibly painful rashes on her hands and feet - instead of the usual symptoms of a fever or persistent cough.Sarah, from Bournemouth, Dorset, said: I looked like I had the plague.“It’s an incredibly painful condition, it’s not pleasant at all.“Not even resting my hands or feet helped, it just got worse over time.”She added: “I never thought I had Covid- at all.“They haven’t made it an official symptom, so there could be people out there with the coronavirus who have no idea.”Rashes have been a common symptom for children with the Kawasaki disease-like condition, linked to Covid.There has been a rise of kids needing intensive care for this condition in recent weeks and many of them have developed rashes.This can be anywhere on the body but in infants this can be more severe in the nappy area.The rash, however, can y in appearance from child to child.The mysterious condition has been compared to toxic shock syndromeand Kawasaki disease.The signs of TSS are:Signs of Kawasaki disease include:Some medics have also reported coronavirus patients having covid toes - where people have developed blisters and purple lesions on their feet.Covid toes can be found on the side or sole of the foot and in some cases has been seen on hands and fingers.The European Journal of Pediatric Dermatology said there had been a epidemic of cases in Italy involving children and young adults.Doctors believe that Covid toes is an inflammatory response to the virus - with some revealing that they have seen the same symptom happen in cases of viral pneumonia or a bad flu.The other theory is that it could be the result of blood vessel clots.Dr Sarah Jarvis, GP and Clinical Director of Patientaccess, told The Sun Online: We know that many infections are linked to a higher risk of clots inside ious blood vessels.It’s possible these foot signs come about because of clots blocking the blood supply of small blood vessels in the feet.It may also be something  entirely – we don’t yet know, but you can be sure that the scientists will be looking to find out.The Department of Health said: “Symptoms of Covid- remain under constant review by an expert scientic group.”Doctors advise thatit’s a new rash you have never seen before then you should seek advice from either NHS  or by speaking to your GP. Dr Jarvis adds: If your child is poorly and has a rash that doesn’t fade when you press a glass against it, you must call .To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: queen reign over coronavirus royal biographer
story: Andrew Morton, author of Diana, Her True Story, says the virus has done more damage to the monarchy than Oliver Cromwell.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesHe " rel"noreferrer noopener"told the : Its terribly sad but I cant see how the Queen can resume her job. The COVID- virus isnt going away soon and will be with us for monthsnot years.[It would be] far too risky for the Queen to start meeting people on a regular basis.She has always loved getting out and meeting people but she cant take the risk.The brutal truth is that her reign is effectively over. COVID- has done more damage to the monarchy than Oliver Cromwell. Corona has practically put Charles on the throne.The Sun Online has gone to the Palace for comment. Previously Buckingham Palace said: The Queen continues to be busy and will follow appropriate advice on engagements.”We have told how the monarch, , is in lockdown at Windsor Castle to stop her from catching the killer virus.Courtiers are already preparing to keep her indoors until at least after the summer — the longest absence from duties in her -year reign.It is understood that Her Majesty does not want to slow down or stop working. But she will not go against any official advice designed to protect people in her age category.The Queen is receiving updates from Parliament through her red boxes and in a weekly call with Prime Minister Boris Johnson.But courtiers are discussing the problems of her ing to frontline work and normal engagements amid the risk of catching the virus.As such, they are preparing for several more months of royal lockdown.And Mr Morton fears it is unlikely the Queen will be allowed toto her normal public duties at all.He reckons Brits are only ever likely to see her on TV or video links — such as with her recent stirring addresses.Trooping the Colour, summer garden parties and a state visit from South Africa have all been cancelled — emptying her diary until the autumn.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more. Her granddaughter Princess Beatrice’s wedding has also been hit — as have annual social events loved by Her Majesty, including the Cha Flower Show, the Derby and Royal Ascot.And the Queen’s birthday honours list due next month is set to be postponed.Mr Morton said: “How can she carry out investitures, meet ambassadors, do walkabouts and visit places without meeting people at close range “If she gets the bug, it could be fatal and would put Prince Philip at risk.“Prince Charles is, of course, over  himself but he has had the virus and probably has immunity now.“The Queen’s speech last month was brilliant and it brought the country together.“To quote Churchill, it was her finest hour, but from now on we are maybe only going to be seeing her on video links.The Queen has been in lockdown with Prince Philip, , at Windsor since March . She would normallyto Buckingham Palace this month, but lockdown means that it is not safe to do so.The Palace will be closed to tourists for the summer for what is believed to be the first time in  years.Extraordinary safety precautions were taken to prevent contact with anyone outside her inner circle when Her Majesty recorded her Covid- address and VE Day speech.Two weeks ago, we revealed the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh are locked down in what one of their top aides has called “HMS Bubble”.Master of the Household Tony Johnstone-Burt said  key members of the staff were staying at the Castle and not living with their families to protect the Queen from the virus.The Queens last official engagements were held at Buckingham Palace on March .They involved the Commanding Officer of HMS Queen Elizabeth and the Bishop of Hereford.Senior royals, including Charles and Camilla, William and Kate and Edward and Sophie, have done all their duties over the phone and video calls. per cent of people who test positive dont have symptoms.That is quite a signicant finding and one of the important things about this disease, in the same way that asymptomatic transmission is one of the things that makes controlling this disease really hard and is novel for any coronavirus, and is one of the things that makes it so dficult.Mr Hancock said the NHS test and trace scheme was part of the solution as isolating those who test positive for the virus would break the chain of transmission, particularly when they would not have otherwise known they were carrying the disease.The briefing was also told a third of Covid-infected Brits" rel"nofollow noreferrer noopener" could not be traced in the NHS Test and Trace programme.Nearly , people were ordered to self-quarantine during the first week of the contact tracing scheme, new NHS stats reveal.The new army of tracers attempted to reach , people who tested positive for the killer disease.Of those ,were traced and contacted, while ,were not reached, or failed to share information about their contacts.In total, from May  to June , , contacts were identied and, of these , were reached and told to self-isolate - title: shamima begum 30k legal aid
story: Figures show her lawyers have claimed £, in legal aid trying to win back her UK citizenship.But sources say the true public bill is at least double that once Home Office staff costs and court time are added in." rel"noreferrer noopener"Begum, , was stripped of her British status by former Home Secretary Sajid Javid. That decision was ruled legal as she has Bangladeshi citizenship.She had travelled to Syria with two other London schoolgirls in February  to join IS.But when The Times found Begum in Syria’s al-Roj refugee camp four years later, " rel"noreferrer noopener"she already had two children and was expecting a third.Tom Hickman QC, for Begum, told London’s Court of Appeal " href"https:www.thesun news  shamima-begum-isis-bride-lawyer-not-fair " target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener"she should be allowed back to the UK to fight her citizenship battle in person.He said Begum was left to “languish indefinitely” and could not have a “fair and effective appeal” which “is wrong in law”.Mr Hickman added: “Because somebody has gone to Syria is not an indication they are a security risk.” Begum and two pals – Kadiza Sultana and Amira Abase – ran away to Syria in February .Begum used her elder sister’s passport to flee with her Bethnal Green Academy friends.The trio flew to Turkey and then crossed the border into Syria with the aid of smugglers.Within weeks of arriving, Shamima was married to Isis jihadi Yago Riedijk, , from Holland.They had two children who died from malnutrition and disease.The couple were separated as they fled Baghouz, the village where a few hundred Isis fighters were holed up in a desperate last stand.Shamima ended up in a Kurdish refugee camp where she gave birth to her third child.Eldest sister Renu revealed that her family had lost contact with her for the “longest time” until she was found by a Times journalist.He said she could face the death penaltyshe were sent to Bangladesh or Iraq and had been subjected to “inhumane and degrading treatment”.But Sir James Eadie QC, for the Home Office, said it was Begum’s fault she could not take part in the appeal because she had “aligned with IS”.The appeal hearing continues.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nurse scotland lockdown cumbernauld kimberley lonnie
story: Kimberley Lonnie, , danced in her bare feet as a DJ blared out disco hits to at least  girl pals.The NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde bank nurse, who covers shts when needed, shared a video and snaps on social media.One pic showed her raising a wine glass and flashing her thigh in a gold-coloured gown.Kimberley, who wrote “aint no party like a kimi party”, told her followers she was in “full-scale party mode” before heading off on annual leave days before the outdoor bash in Cumbernauld.A source said: “You’d expect a nurse to know better especiallyshe’s been on the frontline. This sets a shocking example.”Cops confirmed they were called out at .pm on Saturday.A force spokesman said: “Officers attended, suitable advice was given and people dispersed.”An NHS spokesman said staff should respect social distancing.He added: “Patient and staff safe­ty has not been compromised.”Earlier this week we told how a hospital carer and a frontline coronavirus nurse were being investigated for breaking lockdown rules at a boozy hen do in Dundee.And last week two female cops were pictured getting close to pals at a garden booze-up in Midlothian.

title: london south east north west furlough scheme
story: In geographical breakdowns of where people across the UK have been furloughed, the numbers were highest overall in London, the South East and the North West.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMore than one million were put on the coronavirus job retention scheme in both London and the South West.And , were furloughed in the North West too.That compares to just , in the East Midlands, and , in Wales.In total nearly nine million people have been furloughed across the UK since March.Most of them were in the automobileor food services and accommodation sectorthe latest stats showed.About , were furloughed in manufacturing, and , in construction.According to research from the Centre for Cities, this means Crawley, Burnley and Slouth were the most affected with around of third of the workforce.Its likely this is because of the huge numbers of airport workers who live in many of the towns.Other areas including Birmingham, Hull, Doncaster and Stoke had one in four workers on furlough for at least three-weeks since the scheme was announced.However, university towns like Oxford and Cambridge saw the lowers numbers of furloughed workers.Rishi Sunak, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today: Our unprecedented coronavirus support schemes are protecting millions of vital jobs and businesses across the whole of the United Kingdom - and will help ensure we recover from this outbreak as swtly as possible.We have extended both schemes so they will continue to provide measured support across the UK as we start to reopen the economy.Yesterday was the cut off date for applying for the furlough scheme - but those who are on it can continue to get funding support..million businesses have been able to claim up to  per cent pay for their workers, up to a maximum of £, per month.But in the next few months the scheme will wind down, before being completely shut by the end of October.Businesses will have to start paying towards their employees national insurance costs from August.And they will need to start topping up wages from September, where the Government support will taper away.Across the whole of the UK,  per cent of those potentially eligible for support through the separate self-employment scheme made a claim, with the average value of claim amounting to £,, HMRC said today..million people have made claims for grant support, totaling £.billion. Many businesses are expected to have to lay off workers, however, as hundreds of thousands of them have been shut for nearly three months.However, from next week shops will be able to open once again, and from July pubs and restaurants are expected to be able to .Outdoor attractions including zoos and theme parks will too be able to open their doors to customers in hopes of ing to a new normal.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: schools wont open for key workers over summer
story: It comes after the Government kept schools open for the children of key workers during the Easter and half term breaks so they could carry on delivering vital services to the nation.However, there was no detail on whether there will be any schemes in their place - such as summer camps or holiday clubs.Yesterday Boris Johnson promised a big summer of catch up help for kids to help them deal with the impact of the coronavirus crisis.Were going to get all schools back in September  we possibly can .. but its going to be a big summer of catch up.Were going to keep making sure that kids get the remedial help that they need for the stuff that theyve missed for months and months to come so that they genuinely make up for lost time.More details will be revealed by the Education Secretary Gavin Williamson next week.No stressed today that such camps would last for the summer and beyond. And they did not specy they would be only for the most disadvantaged kids either, leaving the possibility that they could open for millions of children. At the moment grandparents cannot look after children unless they are part of the same household.From Saturday a grandparent or friend can come to help with childcare and form a social support bubble with another family - but onlythey are currently living alone. per cent of key workers have at least one child aged  or below, the IFS has said.Virtually all key workers – including  per cent of health workers and  per cent of education workers – are either without a partner or have a partner in work, who might not easily be able to look after their children. Around  million people are thought to be in a key worker profession - such as in the NHS, a teacher, or someone delivering vital services like food delivery workers.Former education secretary Lord Baker said today: School holidays should be cancelled this year.Teachers and children have already had too much holiday this year and shouldto learning throughout the summer.By September hundreds of thousands,not millions, of schoolchildren will have had no school experience for more than six months. That is shocking, and some of these pupils will never be able to catch up.He also called for the m rule to be reduced to just one, and for teachers and pupils to get daily tests.Education Select Committee Chair Robert Halfon told The Sun The Government have always said schools are going to close over the summer.But its all the more reason why we need an Alan Turning catch up programme to help them.If schools dont open in September, we will have an ice age in terms of childrens learning.However, while the disadvantaged children had to remain the priority, he suggested that the kids of key workers could be included in a summer camp system to help them be able to carry on working - and to keep children learning.I wouldnt turn any child away from learning, absolutely anyone, he added. To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle prince harry discussed megxit before marriage
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex made headlines with their bombshell announcement in January that they were quitting the Royal Family to become financially independent.But claims have today emerged that the couple started talking about plans for a le away from the Royal Family before they even got married.The reports are set to emerge in a new book about the couple which will be released in August. Finding Freedom - said to have been written with the couple’s knowledge - is also set to detail the couples plans for the future following their decision to quit the UK for a new le in LA.A source told The Sun Online: The book will explore the journey that Meghan and Harry went through in coming to the conclusion that they did. It will make clear that far from it being a snap decision that they took a long time to make it.The seeds of Megxit were sown before they even got married. The truth is that Harry had been deeply unhappy for a long time. And he and Meghan openly discussed going in a dferent direction well before they got married.”It comes after it was revealed the book will shatter the notion the American actress is the driving force behind the pair - and instead that it was Prince Harry who wanted to make the change.The insider said: “That word ‘Megxit’ in particular has always angered Prince Harry. It gives the impression that the decision to walk away from the Royal Family was Meghan’s.“The reality is Harry drove that decision. The book will make that clear and explain why it had to happen. The truth is Harry had been unhappy for a long, long time.In the days after his shock announcement that he was stepping away from Royal le, Harry, , hinted at his anger that the finger had been pointed at his we for the decision.Speaking at a charity event he said: “Once Meghan and I were married, we were excited, we were hopeful, and we were here to serve.“For those reasons, it brings me great sadness that it has come to this. The decision that I have made for my we and I to step back, is not one I made lightly.“It was so many months of talks after so many years of challenges. And I know I haven’t always gotten it right, but as far as this goes, there really was no other option.”Contrary to reports, the book - published worldwide on August  - will not be detailing the  year old Suits star’s ongoing fallout with her dad Thomas.The authors - former showbiz journalist Omid Scobie and royal reporter Carolyn Durand - are said to have been given access to friends of the pair, as well as direct access to the Sussexes themselves.Meghan and Harry are now living in the US with their one-year-old son Archie.The couple moved to LA after initially relocating to Canada after revealing they were stepping back as royals.They still have a home in the UK, Frogmore Cottage, and have started to make payments from the £.million refurbishment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince andrew hiding lawyers epstein
story: The -year-old royal this week insisted he had offered to speak with American prosecutors over his friendship with paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.But the lawyer for Epsteins victims today declared no one is above the law as she accused the Duke of York of still hiding.Speaking to Good Morning Britain today, she said: Prince Andrew said months ago he would cooperate but he has failed to do that.Hes hiding behind his attorneys.She said that the public figure should be transparent, adding: Its time to meet with the investigators, and help my clients, the victims of Epstein, to get justice.Andrew is facing ongoing scrutiny over his links to convicted sex offender Epstein, who was at the centre of a web of sex trafficking and abuse before killing himself in jail last August.The Sun this week revealed that the US Department of Justice has filed a mutual legal assistance request to the Home Office - which formally asks for help to question the Royal.But the royals lawyers released an unprecedented statement, insisting he had offered to assist in the investigation three times.Blackfords LLP acting for the royal said: The Duke of York has on at least three occasions this year offered his assistance as a witness to the DOJ. Unfortunately, the DOJ has reacted to the first two offers by breaching their own confidentiality rules and claiming that the Duke has offered zero cooperation.In doing so, they are perhaps seeking publicity rather than accepting the assistance proffered.The Duke has always denied any improper behaviour over his relationship with Epstein, and strongly denies allegations he slept with sex slave Virginia Roberts when she was .But hours later, Geoffrey Berman, the US Attorney for the Southern District of New York hit back.In an explosive statement, Mr Berman Prince Andrew was seeking to ly portray himself to the public as eager and willing to co-operate with an ongoing federal criminal investigationHe said:has repeatedly declined our request to schedule such an interview, and nearly with the probe while Mr Berman is in charge, reports the .Insiders insist that Andrew should remain a witness rather than a target in the federal investigation into Epstein.The source said: The Duke You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Conservative councillor has apologised after sharing racist comments on social media following the wave of Black Lives Matter protests across the world sparked by the death of George Floyd in the US.Debbie Young, a Tory on Stroud District Council, retweeted a post from far-right media commentator Katie Hopkins and another from a US-based Donald Trump supporter branding protesters anti-fascist terrorists. Hopkins had commented on Twitter about protests in London, saying the sad truth is that the real Minority Ethnic in London is White Brits.Ms Young also shared a post which suggested protesters were bone idle and the mindless thugsapos solution. Copies of the posts, which have since been deleted, were passed to the PA news agency. In a statement posted on Twitter, Ms Young said she sincerely apologised for any offence caused. She wrote: On June  in response to the mass protests taking place as a result of the tragic death of George Floyd, I used social media to promote equality. I stated that all lives matter and that I had never taken race into account.At the same time, I said I understood there was anger following George Floydaposs tragic death, but urged protests involving large numbers of people to stop in order to avoid spreading coronavirus, highlighting the need to maintain social distancing.My concern was for peopleaposs safety due to the potential spread of coronavirus.  Some of the protests escalated into violence on June  and I re-tweeted comments made by two iniduals. I accept that in doing so I may have caused concern and upset by my comments and in re-tweeting these posts. This was never my intention. I sincerely apologise for any offence caused. This was no way in indication of support for the views of those iniduals. Neither was it a reflection of my values or my long-held beliefs on equality. I abhor racism in any form. I have worked tirelessly throughout my le to promote equality and to oppose racism. I have always served my community to the best of my ability, treating everyone equally and without prejudice. I will continue to fight against racism and to promote equality in all our communities. In a statement, a Conservative Party spokesman said: We are investigating this matter.

title: beaches fresh bedding among 50
story: NewsBeaches and fresh bedding among  best sights for sore eyesA poll of , adults found a sea view was the best sight for sore eyes, followed by a beach and a sunrise, followed by fresh bedding as many say they suffer from lockdown eyesShareCommentsByAlice HughesJamie Hawkins:,  JUN NewsThe beach is the most welcome sight for sore eyes, a survey has found" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe beach is unbeatable when it comes to a sight for sore eyes. A poll of , adults identied the most welcome scenes in le with experiences enjoyed by the coast, an open beach and the sunrise and sunset, topping the list. Home comforts are also popular with a third loving nothing more than the sight of fresh bedding while  per cent like to look at a clean house. The study, commissioned by Scope Eyecare, also found the UK is a nation of animal lovers, with birds flying around in the morning and a dog happily wagging its tail featuring in the top . Seeing a loved one or friend for the first time in a while also made the list, with  per cent saying this makes them feel happy,  per cent sentimental and  per cent excited. A sixth even said a fully stocked supermarket shelf is a apossight for sore eyesapos - which may have not made the cut prior to the current pandemic. Eye care expert and oculoplastic surgeon, Dr Sabrina Shah-Desai said: Itaposs clear from the research how important sight is in terms of lting peopleaposs spirits. Eyesight and healthy eyes are often taken for granted, and thataposs even despite the prevalence of sore and dry eyes - something which affects half the population.  While aposlockdown eyesapos are a definite result of increased screen time, less natural light and even stress, there are lots of things we can do to ease discomfort and minimise potential longer-term damage. If youaposve been spending long periods of time in front of a screen, check in with how your eyes are feeling by taking the new £EyePromise health test.  The research also found the positive feeling from experiencing a sight for sore eyes lasts almost five hours. As the worldaposs lockdown restrictions ease, the study asked what participants would most like to see and found more than a third of adults have a bucket list of places they want to visit. More than  per cent want to get out and about in UK cities while  per cent would rather go abroad - with the likes of Australia, New Zealand and Japan popular choices. And  per cent of over s said theyaposd like to promise themselves they will see more of their children and grandchildren while a third hope to reunite with old friends they have lost touch with. A further two fths of adults vow to visit more beaches in le and  per cent would like to see more nature. It was found people experience an average of five sights for sore eyes during a typical week, but this has decreased by  per cent during lockdown. But more than half admitted they took nice sights for granted pre-lockdown, with  per cent actively looking for a positive image each day during isolation. More than half of adults even agreed an uplting, unexpected sight has been known to improve their day. However, more than a tenth are apossick of the sight ofapos their computer monitor while  per cent are fed up of looking at the same four walls. Other things people have grown tired of seeing include politicianscertain celebritiesand other peopleaposs selfies . And with people spending more time at home than ever, piles of washing up, a dusty house and an overflowing laundry basket are also unwanted sights. The study also found that the lockdown has resulted in  per cent looking at screens for longer than usual which may explain why a quarter have experienced an increase in tired eyes. A third of respondents notice dry eyes when using a computer, while a sixth do so when scrolling on their phone. Half of those polled, via OnePoll, even claim to experience uncomfortable eyes every day. Dr Shah-Desai added: When concentrating on digital screens our blink rate decreases from eight clinks per minute to just one or two, leading to eye strain and dry eyes.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMost children with conditions such as asthma, diabetes, epilepsy do not need to continue shielding and could go back to school, according to new guidance.The Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Healthhas published a new list for doctors on who should continue to shield and who no longer needs to.The Government will take the list into account. It says many children with conditions such as cerebral palsy and scoliosis should no longer be shielded. It adds that the benefits of school in terms of access to therapies and developmental support outweigh the risk of infection. It said: Children and young people who are cared for just in primary care are very unlikely to need to continue to shield.Do you have a coronavirus story to tell  Email webnew@mirrorThe RCPCH has created two lists, with those on List A being advised to continue to shield. These include children with immunodeficiency and immunosuppression, such as those who have had transplants, children having cancer treatment for acute leukaemia and Non-Hodgkinaposs Lymphoma. Children with signicant impairment in their ability to cough and to clear their airways are also on the list.  On the other hand patients on List B can discuss with their doctors whether it is safe for them to stop shielding, and, for example,to school when these reopen. This includes children with some cardiac conditions, those with sickle cell disease and children who were born premature with oxygen requirements. Those with kidney disease, cystic fibrosis or more serious asthma are also included on the B list.  Dr Liz Whittaker, co-author of the guidance for the RCPCH, said: There is a group of children who are very clinically vulnerable, and they should continue to shield. There is a second group who are currently shielding but may not need to do so. Itaposs important for parents and carers to have a conversation with their specialist to determine the best course of action. These conversations will be informed by knowledge of the severity of the disease, intensity of the treatment, and, for some, their home situation. We need to get the balance right between clinical risks and the social impact of shielding.  We know this has been a tough period for lots of children, young people, and their loved ones. This guidance is to help doctors have evidence-based discussions with parents and carers. She heard a flapping noise and realised it was a bat - before discovering her daughter had been scratched. Charlene ran out of the room and her husband ed to take a photo before opening the bedroom windows and shut the bedroom door to let the bat fly out. But the next day Charlene, of Leavesden, Hertfordshire, woke her daughter Amelie - who started talking about seeing aposbirdiesapos. Her mum was then horried to see a scratch on her face. Brand manager Charlene immediately contacted a doctor who then phoned Public Health England and Rabies UK. It was decided Amelie was to be administered a full course of rabies vaccinations. The incident happened on Sunday May  when Charlene and her husband woke up in the early hours. Mum-of-two Charlene said: aposaposIt took a while to work out what it was. aposaposWe both ran straight out the room - we soon worked out it was a bat. I was shocked and absolutely terried. aposaposWe started googling how to deal with the situation and my husband ventured back inside to open all the windows. aposWe vacated our bedroom for the night and went and slept in our childrenaposs bedrooms so the bat could find its way out. aposaposThe next morning I woke up next to my daughter, and when I moved the curtain she started speaking about aposbirdiesapos.  She said aposis the birdie there apos and thataposs when I saw the marking on her face. I was in complete disbelief. Amelie received the first of her four injections on Tuesday at Watford General Hospital. She is to be administered three more over the course of the next three weeks. Thankfully Amelie is making a speedy recovery and has suffered no serious illness or discomfort as a result of her injuries.Charlene said: aposaposThe doctors carrying out the procedure were all wearing full PPE which is very scary for a two-year-old. aposaposThe vaccinations are frighting enough for the little ones without all that going on. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn artist who spent more than  years turning her cottage into a aposle-size dolls houseapos says her eccentric style of bright interior decoration has scared off any potential buyers. Mary Rose Young has been putting her own touches on the beautul country home in Lydney, Gloucestershire, by hand since , when she purchased the property for just £,. After  years in the house, she put it up for sale in  and estate agents told her that she could expect it to fetch at least £, from prospective buyers. But her hopes of selling up to open a boutique hotel nearby were dashed when only one person could be persuaded to view the house, with Mary Rose saying they aposleft pretty quicklyapos. Despite the decor leaving Mary Rose and her husband Phil Butcher stuck in the home, the -year-old potter has refused to paint over her leaposs work and says she still loves her home, which she also uses as a workspace and gallery. She said: I made this house around my own le and I wasnapost thinking about it being sellable. Weaposre living like two children in a dollaposs house and in retrospect why would anybody  want to buy it  Itaposs like a playhouse for adults. I just thought it might go to a mad collector of my work who might want to buy it, but no one was interested.  Only one person came and looked at it in the year it was on the market and they werenapost here long. I think they had just come out of curiosity to see the decoration and were never interested. The estate agents despaired. I could have painted over all my work, but I didnapost want to. I love my house and the house really works for me. Iaposm a colourful person and I even have pink hair. I like it more and more as I get older.  Since the failure to sell left her dreams of running her own hotel in tatters, Mary has doubled down and put even more effort into putting her mark on the property, turning the courtyard into a bright pink painting studio last year. When she originally bought the house, which is comprised of two knocked-through cottages, she painted the entire home white in a bid to bring more light in, but when that failed she began drawing patterns inspired by her colourful pottery on the walls.  She said after doing one wall orange with red dots it helped distract from the fact thereaposs aposhardly any natural lightapos and it went from there. She added: It became a really fun project for me on the side of my pottery business and I was so galvanised by it I ended up neglecting my pottery at times. Mary Rose has also incorporated her pottery pieces into the homeaposs features, with a pottery chandelier in the sitting room and handmade pottery tiles in the bathroom.

story: NewsHuman bones discovered during gas repair work as forensic officers seal off areaA forensic tent covers the site where the bones were found, while a police car has been keeping guard over night, since the grisly find by gas repair workers in North ShieldsShareCommentsByIan JohnsonLorraine King:,  JUN NewsHuman bones were found by the workers in North Shields " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA police investigation has been launched after staff carrying out gas repair found human bones. The grisly discovery was made on the grounds of Christ Church, near the site of an old graveyard in North Shields.A forensic tent covers the site where the bones were found, while a police car has been keeping guard over night, Chronicle Live reports.Forensic experts are trying to establish the age of the bones which was found just yards from several centuries-old graves. As such, an official at the Anglican church told ChronicleLive that they do not expect the remains to be the result of anything sinister. The graveyard was closed in  so there have been no burials since then, and Albion Road was widened in about , said the female, who declined to be named. Instead, she suggested they may have been remains - buried before the road was widened - that had been missed off during the work a century ago. A spokesman for Northumbria Police said: “Shortly after .am on Wednesday we received a report that suspected human bones had been found during gas work repairs on Albion Road, North Shields. “Officers are now working with forensic experts to determine the age of the bones and the circumstances behind their discovery.  A cordon remains in place and enquiries are ongoing.” The news comes after a creepy wall made from human bones and skulls was discovered under a cathedral in Ghent. Researchers from Ruben Willaert BVBA made the eerie findings while exploring St Bavo’s Cathedral in February.The wall was found to mainly consist of thigh and shin bones from adults, which the researchers believe date back to the late th century.

title: johnny vegas lookalike who moaned
story: NewsJohnny Vegas lookalike who moaned about benefits on TV caught stealing from elderlyTracy MacDonald, from Wythenshawe, Greater Manchester, plundered nearly £, from five elderly women after the "deliberate and targeted attacks"ShareCommentsByGwyn WrightPaul Byrne:,  JUN NewsTracy MacDonald who stole from elderly ladies during distraction theftsLtd" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A female thief was caught after a victim described her as looking like comedian Johnny Vegas.Tracy MacDonald, , posed as a delivery driver or a Good Samaritan to distract her elderly victims before stealing cash. She was arrested after officers recognised descriptions of her as having “fat cheeks” and resembling the TV funnyman. A court heard MacDonald stole from one woman as she pretended to deliver Easter eggs. And prosecutor Gavin Howie said another victim, Mary Wilson, , had £ stolen from her hand after she visited a cashpoint on a shopping trip. He said: “She was approached by a person who she thought was a man but was actually this defendant who said ‘be careful there lots of wrong people about here after money and drugs.’ How prophetic she was. “Shewalked to a nearby farm foods shop and asked them to call police and described the defendant as looking a bit like Johnny Vegas.” At Manchester Crown Court Mrs Wilson, a widow, said: “I am cautious and think of myself as streetwise despite my age. I believe the defendant targeted me and assumed I would not protest as an elderly woman. “I am a strong person and am one of  children and I want to tell the defendant just how wrong what they did was.”  Mr Howie added: “These were quite deliberate and targeted attacks on elderly, disabled and vulnerable people and they caused emotional distress and a loss of confidence for the victims. “In all these incidents she attacked elderly people where she hovered around them before she struck.” MacDonald, from Wythenshawe, Greater Manchester, admitted five counts of theft between February and April , plundering almost £, from five women, and was jailed for a year. She had previous  offences dating back to , including robbery and theft.  In mitigation her lawyer Jane Dagnall said: “These were despicable offences and she has an appalling record and she paints a pathetic persona today. She is an animated character who was previously given a chance by a court, tried hard but failed and her demons got the better of her.’’ Sentencing her, Judge Alan Conrad QC told MacDonald: “You stole from elderly and vulnerable people whose confidence you set to gain and then distract them in order to steal from them. It is despicable that you prey on vulnerable people in this way.”

title: kensington palace staff among employees
story: NewsKensington Palace staff among employees at royal residences facing redundancyRoyal staff at Tower of London, Hampton Court Palace and even Kensington Palace are among those who have been affected by the coronavirus lockdownShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  JUN NewsParade of Beefeaters in London" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Perhaps there is no place in the UK more symbolic of the unequal impact of the coronavirus.Today, many of the , staff who run the country’s richest, most opulent palaces – including the Tower of London, Henry VIII’s home Hampton Court Palace and the state apartments at William and Kate’s London home, Kensington Palace – face redundancy because of the impact of the coronavirus lockdown. The famous red-jacketed Beefeaters, who have guarded treasures including the priceless crown jewels since the th century, are among those who also risk losing their homes, as many live within the grounds of the Tower.Do you have a coronavirus story to share  Email webnews@mirrorOfficially called Yeoman Warders, all are ex-servicemen and women who have achieved the Long Service and Good Conduct medals. The redundancy plan comes as the heritage charity which runs the palaces says having to close its historic doors during lockdown means it is running up a £million shortfall. Staff at Historic Royal Palaces including the Banqueting House in Whitehall – where King Charles I was executed – Kew Palace in London, and Hillsborough Castle in Northern Ireland, are also affected. Meanwhile, HRP plans to “reopen some of the beautul outdoor spaces in our care”.  “We are absolutely shocked by this bombshell,” a member of staff at the Tower of London says. “It’s a bolt from the blue. No one thought it would come to this. We know visitor numbers are way down, and it will take a while to recover – but we are responsible for some of the most iconic buildings in the country. Are they really going to let us go to the wall ” Pandemics have historically fallen unequally on populations, and Covid- is no dferent. But this is not just true of who is dying of Covid- – where clearly race, class and low-pay have played a defining role, and ‘white collar quarantine’ is still protecting those in middle-class jobs. It’s also true of who will lose the most economically. While lower-paid workers have had to keep working and exposing themselves to the virus, we are now starting to see deep job losses from household names such as carmaker Bentley, British Gas and British Airways, and especially in retail and hospitality.  Last week the Prime Minister said: “I am afraid tragically there will be many, many job losses. That is just inevitable.” But he also said the Government would be “activist and interventionist” in helping people in the next phase of the crisis. So far, the Government has refused to step in and help HRP staff. Mark Serwotka of PCS union, which represents many of the Historic Royal Palaces’ workers, says: “The decision to slash wages and cut jobs in HRP is a disgrace. “Our members help guard the crown jewels and keep historic royal monuments and premises clean and safe. They should not be paying for the effects of the coronavirus pandemic. The Government should immediately intervene to secure jobs, pay and pensions of staff going forward.”  HRP chief executive John Barnes says the decision to cut the “dedicated team” has been heartbreaking. “The closure of our six sites for three months has dealt a devastating blow to our finances, which we expect to continue for the rest of the financial year and to be compounded by the slow recovery of international tourism,” he says. “We have taken every possible measure to secure our financial position, but we need to do more to survive in the long term. We simply have no choice but to reduce our payroll costs. “We are heartbroken that it has come to this.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailChristian Brueckner broke into his British ex’s flat through a window and lay in wait for her under her bed in chilling echoes of the Madeleine McCann case. The disturbing incident took place hours after he brutally attacked her in a jealous rage after she innocently hugged another man, she told the Mirror. She claims he repeatedly slammed her head against a wall in the ladies toilets of the Algarve bar where she worked - leaving her a bloodied mess. When the woman ed home she had a “horrible feeling” someone was inside and found Brueckner under her bed. The -year-old believes the German was lying in wait to attack hershe brought another man back to her studio flat. But instead Brueckner, then aged in his late s, chillingly stared at her and said “goodbye” before fleeing.  She said he then embarked on a stalking campaign against the petite barmaid, leaving her too afraid to walk home alone. Portuguese police were twice called out to deal with Brueckner after she complained of the attack and stalking - but he was never charged. The  break-in has eery similarities with Madeleine’s disappearance two years later in nearby Praia da Luz, where he was living. Gerry McCann previously said he believed her abductor was hiding behind a door when he went to check on her. Investigators believe the person who took Madeleine broke into their holiday apartment through a window. The woman, who is still too scared of Brueckner to reveal her identity, today reveals her account of her relationship with the Madeleine suspect.  She tells the Mirror how the German: • Seduced her when they worked together waiting tables in an Algarve restaurant. • Flew into jealous rages when other men paid her attention or even spoke to her. • Branded her a “lazy Brit” when she refused his demands to clean his house. • Chillingly broke into her flat through an open window and hid under the bed after a bust-up. • Now believes her ex, who is in a German prison, could be responsible for Madeleine’s abduction. She said: “Until now I’ve refused to believe someone I was involved with could commit such a horrible and disgusting thing like hurting a child. “But I’m not sure anymore. I’m starting to wonderhe did do it. Andhe did, he needs to be really punished for it.  “It’s chilling to think my ex is suspected of abducting Madeleine McCann. I can’t cope with it.” The woman, from Berkshire, moved to the Algarve town of Lagos in late  after spending several years in the Netherlands. She landed a job in the Taberna de Lagos restaurant - now called Sal e Companhia - alongside Brueckner, a waiter who was two years her junior. “At first I didn’t actually like him that much,” she recalled in a softly-spoken southern accent. “Not for any reason, I just didn’t like him. “I was , he was a couple of years younger than me. Everyone called him Chris. “He liked me, I knew he liked me in ‘that’ way but I wasn’t interested. We slowly became friends in the spring of . “Chris could be very, very charming, very funny and very smooth in the way he talked. “He always dressed nicely, holding the door open for women, that kind of thing. “I was alone here in Portugal, no family around and a bit lonely and I was getting all this attention from this guy. “We got together romantically and at first it was great. The relationship was very nice.” The woman stayed over regularly at Brueckner’s rented farmhouse on the outskirts of Praia da Luz, less than a mile from the Ocean Club.  “I was living in a little flat by myself on the same road as the restaurant where we worked,” she said. “He was living in Luz in the house that has been on the news all week. He was living on his own. “He wasn’t sleazy in the beginning, he was very charming, even chivalrous. “He drove the nice car - the black Jaguar - and was very gentlemanly and spoke properly. “Our sex le was normal. He wasn’t into anything weird with me. “We used to go out to eat a lot. He wasn’t a veggie. He liked to eat Indian food. “He also liked German food. I remember in his house once he made strange German food that I didn’t like at all. “He liked taking me to the beach. He didn’t like the town beach in Lagos. It would always be the West coast beaches, the isolated ones. “He liked those because he didn’t like lots of crowds, that’s what he said. He didn’t like all the tourists in the summer. “At first he seemed very easy-going, very relaxed, but gradually after summer things changed. “During the summer it was good, but during the winter it started to get not so good.” Her first inkling that things were not right came when she bumped into a male friend in Lagos in late .  “We were chatting and suddenly he stopped talking to me, like he was spooked or suddenly remembered something,” she said. “Someone later told me Christian had previously threatened the guy because he’d seen us speaking before. “We also started to argue in the late autumn, early winter. “It would be small things. He would get angry about really small things and I would get upset. “I remember he lost it once because I didn’t clean his house. I said ‘I’ve got my own house to clean, I don’t live here.’ “He was like, ‘You should clean my house, you’re a woman’. “He said he had two Portuguese girlfriends before me and they both cleaned his house even though they never lived there. “I remember saying, ‘but I’m not Portuguese’, and he replied saying ‘English women are all lazy’. “He said he had seen an English girl for a little while and she was lazy like me. “He called her Carol, I think it was only for a few weeks, she was on holiday and they had a fling. “He started to get possessive but it wasn’t to my face, it was behind my back.  “He also began going back and forwards to Germany over that time. He’d stay one week in Germany, then back to Portugal. “I remember feeling suspicious, like something strange was going on, so I looked at his phone. “I found messages in German from someone called ‘B’ saying ‘Ich liebe dich’ - I love you. “It was a German number, and obviously he had been going back and forth to Germany, so I put two and two together. “I confronted him about those and he went crazy, completely crazy. We had a huge fight.” Worse was to come weeks later when Brueckner flew into his jealous rage at theBar - now called Little Breakfast - in the early hours of New Year’s Day. “I started New Year’s Eve working in Taberna de Lagos and then after midnight I worked at another bar,” she recalled. “Chris was at the bar and was drunk. “Some really nice guys I’d made friends with came in from the bar next door to say happy New Year and gave me a hug. “Chris just suddenly came round the bar in a crazy rage and dragged me out in front of everybody. “He grabbed me by the neck, pulled me into the girls toilets and was ramming my head against the wall. “There were people pulling him off me, I think it took four big guys to get him off me.  “They called the police and some officers came. I was on the floor and couldn’t move because I was in shock. “I didn’t talk to the police because I was scared of what he would doit meant he got arrested. “The police soon left after I said I didn’t want to deal with them. “I stayed there the rest of the night recovering and eventually two friends, a guy and his girlfriend, walked me back to my flat. “I went through the security gate and up two flights of stairs, into my flat and closed the door. “Something was really strange inside there. It’s hard to explain, something just felt strange. “I went into the bathroom and the toilet seat was up. I always put the toilet seat down, it’s what I do, so it was another clue. “I was sure someone was either in there or had been in there. “I started looking in the cupboards and then thought I’d check under the bed. “I peeked under and got the shock of my le. He was hiding under there, lying on his back, staring at me. “Can you imagine how that felt  I just froze. I didn’t know what he was going to do to me. “He got out from under the bed, acted like everything was normal, said goodbye to me, walked out and closed the door behind him. “I was there all alone, just shaking and shaking. “I think he was there waiting to see whether I brought anyone home with me. “To this day I still wonder what would have happenedI had brought someone back that night.  “I think, from the previous behaviour, he would have really, really hurt that person and me too.” Despite the vicious beating and break-in, she enraged her friends by rekindling their relationship weeks later. “A lot of people were very, very angry that I went back to him after what had happened on New Year’s Eve,” she admitted. “He begged for my forgiveness, saying he lost control because he was drunk and would not drink again. “He wasn’t a big drinker when we were together, so stupidly I believed him and we got back together with him. “But it was never the same.” The final straw came in mid- when she found women’s underwear in a bag belonging to Brueckner. “I found a pair of knickers that weren’t mine and I got really, really upset about that,” she said. “I confronted him about it at his place and again he went totally crazy. “He drove me back to Lagos. I got out of his car and that was it as far as I was concerned.” But Brueckner had other ideas and began stalking his ex and staking out the restaurant where she worked. “We had to call the police because he kept trying to get in,” she said. “He was stalking me constantly. “One day I was carrying a big tray of drinks and because I wouldn’t talk to him he knocked them out of my hand and they went everywhere. “The police were called and he was banned from coming inside.  “So he would wait outside and follow me. Sometimes it would be begging me to go back with him. “But other times it would be him threatening me or saying I’m going to find out where your parents are and do something to them. “People had to walk me home each night. There was someone each night. Eventually it stopped but it went on for a long while.” She told how Brueckner had a string of ‘relationships’ with older women that led her to believe he could be a gigolo. “There was one lady he used to take out to dinner sometimes, she was a bit older, and he said it was just for company,” she said. “There was another lady, she was much older and I think there may have been something going on between them. “He used to walk her dog and clean her apartment - at least that’s what he told me - and she gave him money for that. “She lived in the centre of town. He took me to her house a couple of times, to see her dog. “He used to go to people’s houses a lot, saying he was going to visit this person and that person. “But the more I think about it the more I wonder what  he was doing. “At the end of the day I never found out who the other underwear belonged to, or who ‘B’ was. “A friend of mine said to me she wonderedhe was some sort of gigolo, doing things for money with older women. “Looking back on it maybe I was very, very naive at that time. I was a lot younger, a lot more impressionable.” The woman moved on with her le but was stunned to get a visit from Portuguese police officers last year. They quizzed her about a rape Brueckner carried out on an American pensioner in Praia da Luz in , shortly after they split. But they never mentioned the Madeleine McCann investigation - even though British and German police already suspected his involvement. “I remember the Madeleine case. I remember being here in Portugal when it happened,” she said. “At first I thought they would find her, but they didn’t and then it became bigger and bigger. “The Portuguese police have spoken to me three times in the past year, but never once did they say it was about Madeleine. “They said it was about him, they were investigating him because they had found out he had raped an old lady in Luz in . “They wanted to know all about him. But I had no idea it was to do with Madeleine also. “They asked me what the relationship was like, what the sex le was like, how he treated me, how he treated women.
