title: musselburgh-marlins-become-first-east-lothian-club-achieve-top-swim-benchmark
story: Already proud holders of a SwiMark certicate, received in , they have now been awarded SwiMark Plus in Scottish Swimmingrsquos accreditation scheme which provides a nationally recognised standard for clubs and swim schools.Head coach Danny Kirkham said: ldquoMusselburgh Amateur Swimming Clubis delighted to have been awarded Scottish Swimmingrsquos highest accreditation, SwiMark Plus.ldquoThis means that Scottish Swimming recognises MASC as a quality programme which is swimmer centred and strives to ensure we provide the best environment possible for our swimmers to reach their full potential.ldquoThis award shows MASC are leading the way in setting new standards for swimming in the community. Through the work undertaken, a development plan which spans the whole club will ensure we keep progressing and moving forward to ensure MASC remains strong and sustainable long into the future.The club has come a long way since its origins in , when swimmers used to hone their skills in the local harbour. The pool at Loretto School was used over the years before the club moved to Musselburgh Sports Centre after it opened in .A year ago, MASCrsquos management committee and coaches held a planning meeting with Scottish Swimming to establish the steps required to be completed in order to achieve SwiMark Plus.A small voluntary project group embarked on reviewing, revising and signing off the extensive SwiMark criteria before engaging in consultative activities across the club, implementing revised and new policies and procedures, analysing data and producing a four year development and action plan.Club president and project manager Gill Downie said: ldquoMany thanks to the small project team heavily involved in delivering this huge feat through endless hours of blood, sweat and tears. It really is a remarkable achievement during the transitional year following chairman Jack Calderrsquos death ndash illustrating MASCrsquos resilience, drive and passion to be recognised as a trusted leader within aquatics sport by offering exceptional all-encompassing swimming development programmes, coaching education tuition and volunteer training within the community. In addition, effective club management and robust financial review systems will ensure MASC is a viable family-friendly resource within East Lothian well into the future.Alan Reed, Scottish Swimmingrsquos regional swimming development manger , added: ldquoWith the committee and other members working hard to gain this award, they have shown that they are a really strong and sustainable club.ldquoA crucial part of the accreditation is the formation of a development plan ndash this ensures that the club is making consistent progress and looks towards the future.ldquoThe club has excellent structures that have been put in place through the process and this has been demonstrated by all the engagement and activity the club has continued through this recent period of change. It has been a pleasure working with the club and helping support them to gain their SwiMark Plus accreditation.The top benchmark is also held by East Lothian Swim Team which provides a performance training environment for countyrsquos top talent. The best swimmers from Musselburgh, Tranent and Haddington Amateur Swimming Clubs train together as a single composite team to achieve success at East District, Scottish National, British and International levels.

title: tim-tales-kings-elephant
story: This week is a story from India which I like, not least because the main character is my favourite animal an elephant.Irsquove loved elephants since early childhood. They are a giant of nature, yet also incredibly intelligent. They feel emotion like we do, in fact possibly more so as the emotional part of their brain is even more developed than that of humans.The old saying that ldquoan elephant never forgets is rooted in this fact. An elephantrsquos emotional intelligence comes from its ability to remember and recall distant memory. Like humans, an elephantrsquos way of being is mostly learned in early le, rather than just based on instinct.They are therefore highly sensitive creatures, influenced and affected by what they experience just as we are.Irsquove heard dferent versions of this tale, and here I have peppered it very slightly with my own style:Once, a king in ancient India owned an elephant. This royal elephant was the joy not just of the king, but also his people.The trainer would ride the elephant every day along the streets. She was a magnicent sight, and children would run out to wave and watch the elephant go by. The trainer took a dferent route each day so people in dferent neighbourhoods all had a chance to enjoy the spectacle.The people felt a real love and affinity for the elephant. Despite her size and strength, she was gentle and affectionate with the people. She would pat children carefully on their heads with her trunk and took care in where she walked.The elephant made people feel safe. More than once she had saved a child from drowning in the nearby river, or from a predator from the jungle. She was a sacred animal to the people.But then people began to notice a change in the elephantrsquos behaviour. She became aggressive and unpredictable. Instead of being patient with the children she knocked them out of her way with her trunk. Instead of being careful where she walked, she deliberately trampled on peoplersquos gardens.The trainer tried his best to control the elephant, but she seemed like a dferent animal. He couldnrsquot understand why she was behaving so dferently.It just got worse, until one day the elephant suddenly set off on a charge and rampaged through the streets, trumpeting loudly as she charged at the terried people, almost killing some of them.The king was horried and ordered the elephant to be confined to her stables. With dficulty she was finally brought under control and locked in.ldquoWhat is going on  asked the king to the trainer.ldquoI have no idea your majesty he replied, ldquoitrsquos asshe is a dferent elephant.ldquoPerhaps the elephant is ill in some way  suggested one of the kingrsquos advisors. But the vet found nothing physically wrong.Then the trainer suggested asking an old man who lived in the jungle as ldquohe is known for his wisdom in understanding animals, perhaps he will know what the cause of this is.So the king sent a messenger and the old man came to the royal palace.ldquoCan you help  asked the king.The old man asked to be left alone with the elephant for a while.When he ed he looked at the king and said: ldquoWhatever is wrong is something that cannot be seen. I must spend some time with the elephant to understand what is troubling her.And so the old man decided to watch over the elephant that night. He smeared himself in mud to mask his scent and hid in a corner of the stable.It was late evening when he heard voices.A group of men had entered the stables from a small side door. They were a gang of murderers. They were using the royal elephant stable as a place to meet and plan their activities. And in so doing they recounted stories of their deeds.Their leader was a man with a cold and ruthless heart. He told stories about his le and deeds, of how hersquod murdered and tortured people he didnrsquot like. Members of his gang laughed and shared their tales too, likewise full of hatred and cruelty.The elephant slumbered as these tales were told, but they were unknowingly heard by her. When the elephant woke the following morning, the tales of hate and violence still swirled in her mind.The old man went to the king.ldquoYour majesty, there are two things you must do to cure the elephant.ldquoThe first is to remove the murderers who meet in the stables at night. The second is you must find the kindest people, who live their lives with love and understanding. Then ask them to meet at night in the stable as the elephant sleeps and tell each other stories from their lives tales of love and understanding. If you do this, then the elephant will be cured.The king looked bemused.ldquoI will most certainly remove the murderers, he said, ldquobut are you saying that stories will cure the elephant ldquoYes, your majesty, replied the old man, ldquobut the right stories. You see we are made from the stories we hear.He went on: ldquoIf we constantly hear tales of hatred and violence then those stories paint our vision of le with fear, loathing and cruelty.ldquoButwe mostly hear tales of love and understanding, then our mind is coloured with kindness for others, and for ourselves.ldquoWe are affected by the stories we hear, evenwe donrsquot realise we have been listening to them.ldquoYour elephant was unknowingly listening to tales of hatred and killing every night as she slept. So her mind was filled with hate and distrust her vision of the world changed and so did her behaviour.ldquoIf she hears good stories then she will eventually become her kind self again.The king nodded in understanding and agreed to act on this. Within a few weeks the elephantrsquos behaviour had changed for the better.ldquoYou are indeed wise in the ways of elephants, the king said to the old man.ldquoThe truth in this is not just for elephants, the old man replied.ldquoPeople are like your elephant the stories they hear will paint their world and affect how they live in it.The king nodded once again.ldquoMy job is done, said the old man, ldquoI will nowto the forest.ldquoBy the way, your elephant will have a calf, and her calf must hear good stories too.ldquoHow can I pay you for your wisdom  asked the king.The old man thought for a moment, then said: ldquoBe a king who tells good stories tales of kindness and understanding. And be a good listener to the stories told by your people.ldquoThen you will be a truly great leader and your kingdom will flourish and be a happier place.ldquoIf you do that, it will be my greatest reward.

title: tell-difference-symptoms-hay-fever-covid-19
story: It comes as the weather gets warmer and summer approaches, with hay fever sufferers having to cope with more pollen in the air.But could coughing be a sign of hayfever, and as coronavirus sticks around, how can you tell it apart from allergy symptoms Heres what you need to know.What is hay fever Hay fever, also known as seasonal allergies, tends to flare up between late March and September according to the NHS, as this is when itrsquos warm, humid, windy and when pollen count is at its highest.Healthline says: ldquoWhen your body is exposed to allergens, it releases histamines.ldquoHistamines are meant to protect you from harm, but they can also cause the allergy symptoms that make some seasons uncomfortable.Hay fever and its symptoms are not contagious for those around you.Is coughing a symptom of hay fever Hay fever comes with a lot of dferent symptoms, one of which is a cough.Other symptoms include:The NHS says thatyou also suffer from asthma, you might also experience:How do I tell the dference between hay fever and coronavirus With hay fever and coronavirus having overlapping symptoms, like coughing, loss of smell and headaches, some people might get confused about what their symptoms mean.Most hay fever sufferers are affected from childhood, and will probably be expecting their symptoms every year around the same time.If yoursquove never had hay fever before, and you suddenly begin experiencing symptoms, itrsquos understandable that this might cause concern.Patient Info says: ldquoAround one in five people with hay fever get symptoms for the first time over the age of , so therersquos no reason to assume an adultrsquos symptoms canrsquot be caused by hayfever just because theyrsquove never had it before.Marc Donovan, chief pharmacist at Boots, says: ldquoHay fever doesnrsquot cause a high temperature and most people donrsquot feel unwell.The NHS explains that the two main symptoms of Covid- are a high temperature and a new, continuous cough.A high temperature means that you feel hot to touch on your chest or back - you do not need to measure your temperature.A new, continuous cough is also defined as ldquocoughing a lot for more than an hour, or three or more coughing episodes in  hours.Boots Pharmacy released an graphic which shows the dference between hay fever symptoms and coronavirus symptoms, and included information like:How do I treat hay fever There is currently no cure for hayfever, but there are things you can do to help your symptoms according to the NHS, which includes:A pharmacy can also help with hay fever as they can provide you with things like antihistamine tablets or nasal sprays to help with your symptoms.

title: glasgow-set-enter-lockdown-phase-2-next-week---changes
story: The First Minister saidthat, "at least in part", more of the coronavirus lockdown measures will be eased on at the next formal review on June .At the Scottish Governmentdaily briefing, Ms Sturgeonsaid: "I am optimistic that, ten days from now at the next formal review, we will be able to move, at least in part, into the next phase of our routemap out of lockdownwith more inidual freedoms restored and more businesses able to open up and operate again."But that depends on each and every one of us, so please, please, stick with it for now."It comes as figures shows for a second day in a row there were no new deaths reported overnight in Scotland.This comes with the message of caution, with fewer deaths usuallyrecorded over the weekends.Nicola Sturgeon optimistic of entering Phase  next weekWhile not all of these may take place, these are some of the measures set out in the routemap out of lockdown for Phase .Seeing friends and familyFrom June , people in Scotland may be able to meet people from other households indoors for the first time - while maintaing physical distancing and hygeine measures.You will also be able to meet with larger groups including family and friends outside.Shopping and pubsFrom Phase , the Scottish Government says pubs and restaurants CAN open outdoor spaces such as beer gardens - so long as social distancing measures can be maintained.Outdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.Previously closed small retail units can also reopen - again with the underlying pin of physical distancing.SportsThe resumption of professional sport, in line with public health advice, is currently planned for Phase .Likewise,sports courts and playgrounds may also be able toreopen from this date.However gyms will not be able to reopen until Phase .Weddings and worshipIt is hoped that under Phase , marriages and civil partnerships can take place in Scotland with minimal number of attendees.The routemap also says places of worship will be able to reopen for private prayer - but not for extended groups until Phase .TransportPeople may be able to drive locally for leisure under the Phase  routemap.Public transport can increase their capacity but will remain signicantly limited to allow for physical distancing.WorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - title: black-lives-matter-every-scottish-street-linked-slave-trade-revealed
story: Black Lives Matter protests across the globe have thrust our nationrsquos history into the spotlight once again ndash with thousands taking to the our streets and parks joining calls from around the world for racial equality.The catalyst for the growing unrest: the death of -year-old black man George Floyd in Minnesota, when a white police officer knelt on his neck for more than eight minutes.And with support growing for the renaming of streets in Scotland linked to the slave-trade, research from the University College Londonhas revealed the true extent of Scotlandrsquos dark ties.The death of George Floyd has sparked mass protestsAcross the country, more than  addresses that benefited from the money in the slave-trade have been identied.Edinburgh proved to be a major benefactor in the list ndash with more than  addresses highlighted.In Glasgow, just under  places were noted in the list, with  in both Ayrshire and the Borders.There were  cases in Fe, with a further  in Stirling and  in Inverclyde, West Dunbartonshire and Argyll and Bute.BLM protests took place across Scotland over the weekendAcross the UK, there are  addresses listed on the map.As the researchers from the UCLs Centre for the Study of the Legacies of British Slave-ownership note: "Each address pinpoints a slave-owner or direct beneficiary in a particular place at a specic time."You can view the interactive map HEREwith all the locations listed by the UCL.You can find out more information about the address and occupiers past by clicking on the blue markers.Follow the link above to view the interactive map

story: Following a closed test in London last month,  service station locations on UK motorways will open for takeaway from next Wednesday.Then, from June  onwards, they will gradually roll-out to high streets, towns and city centres.The fast-food chain also plan a trialled relaunch of the McDonaldrsquos breakfast service from that date.There is currently one McDonalds restaurant in East Lothian, in Dunbar on Spott Road beside the towns Asda store.McDonaldrsquos UK  Ireland CEO Paul Pomroy said: ldquoWersquore delighted to be back.ldquoI am extremely proud of our employees, franchisees and suppliers who are working so hard in so many communities already.ldquoThe high street is at the heart of our business, it is where we started in the UK, in Woolwich over  years ago.ldquoIn line with Government changes to lockdown restrictions, over the next few weeks and months wersquoll reopen on high streets across the UK and in towns and cities in Ireland.ldquoI know that opening those doors will be incredibly satisfying for our restaurant teams, but it will also mean them getting used to the measures we have implemented to enable us to safely .ldquoSo please continue to support them and follow the social distancing measures wersquove introduced for the safety of our teams and you.What do McDonaldrsquos say about new safety measures -We will provide clear signposting and floor-markings to create a one-way system around our restaurants for you and our delivery partner couriers-We will only allow certain numbers of people inside our restaurants at a time to help you and us adhere to social distancing ndash this will y depending upon the restaurant size and lay-out-When you visit us for takeaway, we will welcome you inside when a space becomes available, and wersquoll ask you to sanitise your hands at the cleaning stations we are introducing in all restaurants-We will have fewer self-order screens switched on and will sanitise those in use at least every  minutes. You can also order via the My McDonaldrsquos app-If you can visit alone to collect your food, please do so, however we know this isnrsquot always possible ndash children are of course still welcome, but for now wersquoll be putting away our crayons and colouring sheets and keeping the play areas and digital play areas closed-Our seating areas, customer toilets and lts will remain closed-As our dining areas will not be open, our recycling points will also remain closed but most of our packaging can be recycled so please do dispose of it responsibly and recycle wherever possible when you get home-To help protect our employees and other customers, we ask you not to visityou feel unwell.

title: dentists-plan-reopen-glasgow-practices-open-doors-england
story: Currently all practices are closed apart from telephone triage, with increased care offered at emergency dental hubs and urgent dental care centres.Scotlandrsquos Chief Dental Officer Tom Ferris detailed out the plans in a letter published yesterday as he updated the progress of the lsquoremobilisation of NHS Dental Services in Scotlandrsquo as we move our way out of the coronavirus lockdown.He writes that as part of the plans, the Scottish Government hopes to reintroduce services ldquoon a phased basis over the course of this month.The precise date will be confirmed at the next -weekly review of lockdown regulations, which takes place on June  ndash with First Minister Nicola Sturgeon already confirming she is ldquooptimistic the country will move into Phase  of the route map out of lockdown on that date.So, what does this mean If Scotland does indeed move into Phase  from June , then all dental practices would be permitted to open to see patients with ldquourgent care needs from this point ndash provided they are non-aerosol generating procedures.Mr Ferris however notes that ldquonot all dental practices will be able to open at the same time as some practices may take longer to prepare.He continued: ldquoThe start date is not to be considered a target ndash practices must be certain they can safely open before they do.Scotlands route-map out of coronavirus lockdownhttps:t.co LNSqkNz pic NojpLpSdcWhat about Phase  and From Phase , which is a currently  date but could be as soon as mid-July, all dental practices can reopen to see registered patients, even without ldquourgent needs.And from Phase , there will be a limited introduction of aerosol generating proceduresto dental practices, which will be dependent on evidence of risk and possible mitigation.How does this compare to England #Dental practices in England were permitted to reopen yesterday for the first time since lockdown rules were introduced.There, the British Dental Associationhas told practices to prioritise patients with urgent need and vulnerable groups when resuming services, with an increase in demand expected to work through the backlog.But not all dentists down south were happy with the decision ndash in a warning that could be a sign of things to come in Scotland.They want the UK Government to provide further support, saying so far it has been ldquotoo limited.One dentist has described theto work as ldquonerve-wracking.The BDA union has asked for dentists to be granted key worker status and access to the Government supply chain on PPE, as one industry survey suggests only around one third of surgeries in England, %, opened yesterday.

title: new-musselburgh-racecourse-operators-hope-take-return-racing-month
story: The racecourse hopes to see aof racing, behind closed doors, at the end of the month with back to back fixtures proposed on June  and July .And at a online video call meeting on Tuesday of Musselburgh Racing Associated Committee , which oversees the racecourse, it was revealed new operator Chester Racing Company hopes to be in place before the first date.East Lothian Councils legal adviser Carlo Grilli said negotiations over the takeover were ongoing but it was hoped Chester would be in place later this month.He said: "Given the end of June has a potential fixture the proposal for Chester would be to take over a few days prior to the end of June to get a few days prior in."East Lothian Council has been negotiating with Chester after it was named the preferred bidders for a contract to operate the course last year.The course, which sits on common good land, had previously been run by a governance committee made up of elected councillors and representatives of Lothians Racing Syndicate ndash originally Musselburgh Joint Racing Committee and more recently MRAC.The decision to bring in a third party operator came after the British Horseracing Authority threatened to remove Musselburghrsquos racing licence when relations between the members of the previous committee became toxic one-month extensions were put in place to allow the new operator to come in.Last month the BHA extended the licence until the end of October.Councillor Fiona ODonnell, MRAC chairperson, said she and fellow members had held talks with Chester over their involvement in the town in the future.She said: "It says a lot about Musselburgh that they are still very keen. Chester have some really positive intentions in terms of the local community as well and this is good news."Councillor Stuart Currie, MRAC member, welcomed news Chester was still keen to take over, pointing out the council could have been back to "square one"they had taken a step back during the Covid- crisis.He said: "That Chester is still taking over the running of the race course is really positive. It could have been the case that some people might have turned around and said they did not want to do anything right now and we would have been back at square one."It is important for the racing industry and it is important for the staff at Musselburgh."The committee which met via Skype chose to hear a health and safety report and report by the racecourse general manager in private citing commercial reasons for not discussing them in public.

title: small-car-parks-reopen-locals
story: Most of the local authoritys coastal car parks remain closed as it tries to deter daytrippers from heading to East Lothian.However, smaller rural car parks and a few of the more remote coastal car parks have been reopened.The local authoritydecided to reopen some of the facilities quietly and "without fanfare" as it aimed to keep visitors local.Public toilets and childrenrsquos play areas remain closed and Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesman, appealed to people to stay within their local areas.He said:ldquoIn line with Scottish Government guidance, we have decided to proceed with a partial re-opening of car parks ndash focused on smaller coastal and inland countryside parking sites."This will provide local residents, particularly those who are less mobile and may have dficulty accessing the countryside by foot or bike, with more access to the coast or countryside for leisure and exercise.ldquoWe do understand why people from other areas wanted to visit our beautul coast and beaches during the recent spell of warm weather. But progress in tackling Covid- remains fragile."Therefore, given the need to reduce the risk of popular beauty spots becoming crowded and potentially unsafe, our larger coastal car parks will remain closed at this time.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming visitors from further afield to these sites and where in East Lothian when it is safe to do so but at the moment we would ask that people do not travel to beauty spots from out with their local area."Car parks now open for local residents at coastal sites are:Back Sands and Mountjoy, Fisherrow, MusselburghLevenhall Links, MusselburghMorrisonrsquos Haven, Prestongrange, and Prestongrange Mining MuseumPreston Links Sailing Club, PrestonpansPond Hall, on The Promenade, Port Seton North Berwick East BeachLinkfield, John Muir Country Park Shore Road, West BarnsWhite SandsBarns NessSkaterawThorntonloch.Inland car parks now open are:Butterdean, near GladsmuirWoodhall, near PencaitlandTraprain LawPencraig, both near East LintonHopetoun , north of Haddington andPencaitland Railway Walk.

title: pies-gravy-power-vegan-shroomballs-urgently-recalled-supermarkets
story: Heres a round-up of the latest product recalls.Sainsburys are recalling a product from their vegan range over fears that it may contain plastic.Plant Pioneers Vegan Shroomballs have been recalled due to the potential presence of "small pieces of white plastic" which would make the product unsafe to eat.Sainsburys released a statement saying that no other products had been affected by the contamination.It said: "It has been brought to our attention that the above product may potentially contain small pieces of white plastic."We are asking customers who have purchased this product toit to their nearest Sainsburys store for a full refund when they next visit for groceries  other essentials."Food Standards Agency advise that those who are in possession of the product shouldit to the store from where it was brought next time they visit for essential shopping.Those who are vulnerable or shielding have been advised by Sainsburys to call its careline on   or by email to customer.service@sainsburysThe product details are as follows:Name: Plant Pioneers Vegan ShroomballsSize: gUse by date: All dates between June  and ,Fryrsquos Family Foods haverecalled Fryrsquos Mushroom Country Style Pie because it contains milk which is not mentioned on the label.The recall means the product is a possible health risk for anyone with an allergy or intolerance to milk or milk constituents.Frys said: "Due to a packaging error, some boxes contain chicken and ham pie, which is also not suitable for people avoiding the consumption of meat. The affected product has only been sold in Sainsburyrsquos stores."The Food Standards Agency added: "If you have bought the above product and have an allergy or intolerance to milk or milk constituents, or avoid the consumption of meat, do not eat it."Insteadit to the store from where it was bought for a full refund when next visiting for groceries and other essentials."Alternatively contact Fryrsquos Family Foods UK on   or by email to enquiries@frysfamilyfoods"The product details are as follows:Name:Fryrsquos Mushroom Country Style PieSize: gUse by date: June , Allergens: MilkPremier Foods have recalledBisto Original Gravy Powder because it contains milk which is not mentioned on the label.This means the product is a possible health risk for anyone with an allergy or intolerance to milk or milk constituents.This only affects products sold in certain Asda stores in the north of England with lot number  A and time codes between : and :.Those who have bought the product and have an allergy or intolerance to milk or milk constituents should not eat it.Customers making an essential trip to the store where it was bought fromcanthe item in-store for a full refund.Alternatively, shoppers can contact Premier Foods Customer Service at www.bisto or call    , or call Asda Customer Relations on   .The product details are as follows:Name:Bisto Original Gravy PowderSize: gLot number:  A Use by date: End of March Allergens: Milk

title: east-lothian-mp-quizzes-prime-minister-food-standards
story: Mr MacAskill quizzed Boris Johnston during a virtual Prime Ministers Questions over what would be done to protect current animal welfare and food standards.And he accused the UK Government of failing to "enshrine protections in the agriculture bill".Referring to another of the ongoing debates around a future trade deal with the USA, Mr MacAskill asked the Prime Minister to make an assurance ldquothat we wonrsquot face chlorinated chicken on our table, along with Kentucky-fried medicine in our hospitals.Mr MacAskill called on the Prime Minister to be clear that high standards must be protected and to establish a commission to look at food standards.He said: "I have had a number of constituents contacting me recently to express signicant concerns about the UK Governmentrsquos trade policy." It is clear that food standards, animal welfare, and environmental concerns are not a priority for this government who seem to be more interested in getting any trade deal done to prove a point about Brexit, rather than for the benefit of the people of these islands."The long-awaited Brexit benefits are receding further into the distance every week and the future under an American Trade deal looks grim indeed for the sector and citizens.Last month Minette Batters, the president of the National Farmerrsquos Union ,said: ldquoOur trade policy must reflect our moral responsibilities to the planet and the people and creatures that live on it ndash protecting our natural environment, caring for our farmed animals, and working toward a more sustainable, climate-friendly way of farming and food production. These are issues that cannot be wished away or presumed dealt with by brief pledges in a manesto or verbal assurances in media interviews.Mr Johnson responded to Mr MacAskills question,saying ldquoon leaving the EU, as we have, we will be able to increase our animal welfare standards.

title: countys-slavery-links-highlighted
story: Leading human rights campaigner Sir Geoff Palmer, Professor Emeritus in the School of Le Sciences at Heriot-Watt University, Edinburgh, highlighted James Wedderburn, a plantation and slave owner who lived in Inveresk Lodge, near Musselburgh, saying that James and his brother John went to Jamaica after their dad was hanged.They both stayed there for a number of years, buying land and slaves before ing to Scotland in the s. On Jamesrsquoshe bought and moved into Inveresk Lodge, marrying into the Colville family. His daughter also later married Lord Selkirk. James and his we are buried in Inveresk churchyard.Sir Geoff said: ldquoThatrsquos very important. He went to Jamaica after his father was hanged, they had no money, they came back, he buys the Lodge and his daughter marries into British aristocracy. They came back from Jamaica, where they made a lot of money and made a name for themselves, his daughter married into the Scottish aristocracy. The fact is that itrsquos a good story and itrsquos important, and itrsquos why street names are important.There are streets in Inveresk named after the Wedderburn family, such as Wedderburn Court and Wedderburn Terrace.When askedthese street names should be changed, Sir Geoff said: ldquoYou let people know information about the name and that these streets were, for example, named after this family who were slave owners and lived nearby.He added that plaques could be placed next to such street signs, alerting and educating people on the history behind the name, something that could be beneficial to future generations.Sir Geoff noted the important role stories like these played in East Lothian history. He said: ldquoItrsquos an important part of East Lothian and Inveresk history andyou remove that or rename it and call it something , you could be removing part of the history of East Lothian.ldquoSome of the street names, I donrsquot want them removed.ldquoBy removing them you are removing the deed, andyou remove the deed people are not going to be aware in the future and then history could be dferent. If you change a bit of the street name, a bit of history is then missing.ldquoWe need to address the issues black people have and the issues that cause their lives to be dficult rather than changing statues. You need to address the social issues and the disparity.He added that history like this should be included in the curriculum and taught in schools.When askedthere were any statues or works of art in East Lothian which they were reviewing following the BLM movement and demonstrations, a spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe views of local communities about who should be celebrated in their towns and villages is extremely important and East Lothian Council will listen to any concerns expressed on these matters.Parts and people of East Lothian with links to the slave trade are highlighted on the website: www.ucl.ac.uk lbs maps britain

title: east-lothian-not-immume-racism-demonstrations-held
story: In North Berwick on Sunday, more than  people joineda peaceful protest, ensuring they were two metres apart in line with social distancing.And in Musselburgh, the townrsquos archer sculpture was dressed to support the cause while Black Lives Mattersigns were erected at Memorial Park, Haddington, though later vandalised.The demonstrations in East Lothian and throughout the world follow the death of George Floyd, in Minneapolis, after a police officer knelt on his neck for almost nine minutes.Seventeen-year-olds Abbie Greenwood and Maya Chukwuma organised a well-attended BLM gathering close to North Berwickrsquos East Beach.Abbie said: ldquoWe just wanted to show our support even for a small town, and to spread awareness to the local community.Grandmother Alexandra Graham, from North Berwick, said: ldquoI was delighted to join the protest and I want to laud the young people who put it together."Like many others, I couldnrsquot get through to the protest in Edinburgh because of the lockdown, but making a stand matters to me very much."My young granddaughter will face racismand discrimination in the future so I donrsquot just want to be in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement, Irsquom also trying to learn how best to support my granddaughter as she grows.Meanwhile, in Haddington, BLM signs were placed outside the townrsquos Memorial Park.Phoebe Hayman, who lives in the town, was joined by friends in putting up the signs, which had messages including: ldquoIt is not enough to be non-racist be anti-racist and ldquoBlack Lives Matter.The -year-old, studying politics and French at the University of Glasgow, said: ldquoWe feel really passionate that this is an issue that affects everyone and all communities.ldquoWe wanted to go to the protest in Edinburgh but, due to Covid, a lot of people have key workers living with them or vulnerable people and it was not worth the risk.ldquoWe decided to do something that people will see and maybe make them think.However, the posters, which were put up at the park, at the junction of Court Street, Station Road, Hope Park and Knox Place, did not win the approval of everyone.Phoebe added: ldquoWhen we put them up, someone drove past and booed, which is horric.Similarly, white spray paint was used to cover two of the posters, with the words ldquowightdoes towritten over ldquoBlack Lives Matterrsquo.Phoebe and friends have also received a number of messages from people showing their appreciation for the efforts. The signs have been repainted.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, who represents the Haddington and Lammermuir ward, said: ldquoIt was the issue of racism and its corrosive impact on society which first got me interested and involved in politics as a young person growing up in Scotland.ldquoIt remains a blight on our society and the Black Lives Matter campaign rightly highlights that.ldquoSadly, racism certainly exists in East Lothian and as a councillor Irsquove supported businesses, families and young people who have experienced racist incidents.ldquoThere is still a long way to go to tackle this endemic problem which we all have a responsibility to help confront and address.For centuries racism has been a systemic problem in Scotland and the rest of the UK, acknowledged Iain Gray, MSP for East Lothian.He said: ldquoThis ingrained prejudice still blights the lives of non-white people across our country today.ldquoIt can be seen in all aspects of le, from education and employment opportunities, to our legal and political systems.ldquoThe latest example of this is the growing body of evidence pointing to the fact that the socio-economic factors at play in the lives of many black and minority ethnic people make them more at risk from dying of coronavirus.ldquoWhile East Lothian is generally a welcoming and inclusive area, we are not immune from the effects of this institutional racism and discrimination and there have certainly been racist incidents here over the years.ldquoEvery community can always do more to combat and campaign against all forms of racism, including anti-semitism and Islamophobia, which is why I support peaceful and responsible protests which observe public health rules by Black Lives Matter campaigners.ldquoI was very sorry to hear that BLM signs in Haddington had been vandalised ndash a sign that we still have a long way to go on this issue.County MP Kenny MacAskill said that what was unfolding in America was ldquotragic and frightening but an organised challenge to the racism shown there had been a long time coming."Throughout the sweep of history we see that certain moments acted as flash points, he said."The murder of George Floyd seems to have been one such flash point in the US.ldquoAt the same time, the global spread of the Black Lives Matter movement has shown that no country is immune to racism.ldquoScotland is no dferent and laws require enforced and attitudes need challenged.ldquoThe vandalism of peaceful protestersrsquo signs in Haddington was shameful but doesnrsquot reflect the views of the overwhelming majority of East Lothian citizens.ldquoAs I understand it, all the protesting in the county was done peacefully, and with propersocial distancing."Therersquos much more to be done and efforts need to be renewed as challenges will grow post lockdown, but Irsquom sure folk in East Lothian will continue to speak out against injustice and racism wherever it happens and I will be with them, helping to ensure that steps are taken to address racism and inequality wherever it is found.Councillor Willie Innes, East Lothian Council leader, said: ldquoBlack Lives Matter is a global movement highlighting the discrimination, inequalities and violence experienced by black communities in many western societies.ldquoRecent events in the USA have resulted in iniduals and groups collectively lending their support to building more inclusive communities and tackling racial discrimination in all of its forms.ldquoI believe East Lothian to be a welcoming county but each of us need to reflect on how best we can challenge racial discrimination within our own communities and work places.Foysol Choudhury, chair of the Edinburgh and Lothians Regional Equality Council , said they as an organisation condemned all forms of discrimination and inequality in all aspects of le.ldquoThe Black Lives Matter movement is another form of protest against the injustice and inequalities they as a group face and have been facing for decades, he said.ldquoEquality is about ensuring that each person has an equal opportunity in society. For example, a personrsquos background, ethnicity, disability, skin colour, culture and religion should not determine or undermine these basic human rights. We work to eliminate all forms of discrimination and inequalities and promote human rights.When askedthere was a racism problem in East Lothian, Mr Choudhury said: ldquoYes we know there is a problem with racism because we deal with cases all the time so we know itrsquos still re in our communities.An example he gave involved a black man who was racially discriminated at work through how he was treated and dealt with by white members of staff.Staff are said to have made comments about his accent, racial jokes about his culture and where hersquos from.Mr Choudhury added: ldquoWe also have many cases of BAME residents who are racially abused by their neighbours and some have faced graffiti on their doors and car as well as verbal abuse on a daily basis. These are just a few of the issues we see on a regular basis.ldquoELREC as an organisation and board members, as well as our president Sir Geoff Palmer, are very active in Edinburgh and Lothians to do all we can to help our communities and society to fight racism at all levels.Conservative Councillor Craig Hoy, who represents the Haddington and Lammermuir ward, said:"Racism is abhorrent and should be called out and stamped out wherever it occurs."We all have a duty to confront racismand Isupport those who are campaigning here in East Lothian and across Scotland."

title: schoolgirl-draws-picture-thank-keyworker-parents
story: Lucy Malcolm, nine, lives near Pinkie Primary School with mum Dianne, who works in the maternity department at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh dad Keith, who works for Royal Mail -year-old brother James, an apprentice electrician and -year-old brother Craig, a pupil at Musselburgh Grammar School.Lucy, a primary four pupil at Campie Primary School, used chalk to draw the image without any help.Her gran Ann Malcolm, who lives on the townrsquos Riverside Gardens and is a former headteacher of Windygoul and Saltoun Primary Schools, said: ldquoItrsquos quite amazing.ldquoHer parents were taken aback and really appreciated it.ldquoSome of the neighbours also went over to have a look at it.ldquoThatrsquos what itrsquos all about, though, thanking these key workers and celebrating them.Ann said that the family have been coping well with lockdown, with Lucyrsquos brothers James and Craig helping to look after Lucy while their parents were at work.She added that she was looking forward to reuniting with the family and her grandchildren for a socially distanced chat.

title: east-lothians-tourism-industry-reopen-july
story: Tourism Secretary Fergus Ewing, MSP, today announced plans to allow tourism and hospitality sectors to reopen from July the country continues to move forward into the third phase of lting lockdown restrictions.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray welcomed the move but warned comprehensive guidance would be needed to make sure the industry "got it right first time".He said: "Our tourism and hospitality sectors were among the first to be ordered to close as the Covid- lockdown began, which has had a devastating impact on many local businesses and visitor attractions.ldquoIt is welcome that they are now being given the go ahead to start planning to re-open, but we have to get this right first time. Businesses and others in the sector have faced huge financial losses due to this crisis, and there must be absolute clarity about what this announcement means for dferent parts of the sector.ldquoWith the possibility that this date could be pushed back for safety reasons, it is vital that Scotlandrsquos tourism and hospitality businesses, their staff and customers have absolute transparency from the Scottish Government about any potential changes that may need to be made."There must be comprehensive support and guidance made available to businesses and the public so that there is no confusion about how this can be handled safely.ldquoBusinesses in the tourism and hospitality will also need ongoing financial support through the recovery stage and I have written to the Finance Secretary to ask what the plans are for delivering this support.Last week Councillor Craig Hoy, ward member for Haddington and Lammermuir, wrote to East Lothian Councils chief executive Monica Patterson outlining his ideas for allowing restaurants, cafes and bars to reopen by making public spaces near them available to create an outdoor experience.Mr Hoy said: ldquoFor example, in Haddington the area outside of the Corn Exchange, the area to the front of the Waterside Bistro, the area outside of the former George Hotel and the area outside the Poldrate Centre, and the neighbouring riverside grassed area, could all be developed in this way, while ensuring hours of operation do not negatively impact local residents.A spokesperson for the council said at the time that it was already working with a range of stakeholders to ensure that local businesses can open as soon as Scottish Government guidance permits.

title: bus-stop-transformed-art-gallery-tyninghame
story: Tyninghame, like many communities across East Lothian, has worked hard to offer support and help to residents during lockdown.Throughout the pandemic, the village bus stop has become the central point for people to safely collect anything from teaching materials for children to the weekly vegetable order and tomato plants.Now, as lockdown restrictions are beginning to ease, Tyninghame residents are looking to the future.All have contributed pictures and collages to the Art in the Bus Stop project.Each work of art has been based around the theme of My Future Planet, with a community vote deciding the winners.

title: dunbar-residents-get-ready-civic-week-competition-home
story: The town would be gearing up for their annual Civic Week competition, which was due to get under way this weekend,it was not for the coronavirus.The global pandemic meant the popular event, which was due to mark its th anniversary, had to be cancelled.However, organisers came up with three competitions ndash a best dressed house, window and scarecrow ndash to ensure the milestone was still marked.Dunbar Community Council had planned week-long celebrations, which also would have toasted the th anniversary of the granting of a Burgh Charter to the town by King David II.George Robertson, who heads the organising committee of Civic Week, previously told the Courier the two milestones were ldquotoo important to be missed.The scarecrow should ideally represent any well-known person connected to Dunbar over the past  years, such as Oliver Cromwell, John Muir, Black Agnes or Robert Wilson.All entries should be sent in by pm this eveningto email address dunbarcivicweek@outlook with judging taking place on Saturday.

title: greywalls-preparing-welcome-back-guests
story: The redesigned luxury hotel will see diners able to order their meals using an app and food served to side tables to avoid contact.Rooms will be disinfected and sealed ahead of guests arrivals and staff will wear Personal Protective Equipment.Owners of the Gullane hotel, Inverlochy Castle Management International , say they hope to open on July  - a date announced by Tourism Secretary Fergus Ewing, MSP, today, depending on progress into phase three of the easing of lockdown.And the company, which also oversees Inverlochy Castle, Andy Murrayrsquos Cromlix, Crossbasket Castle, Blanefield House, among other venues and several rural self-catering lodges, says it aims to keep some of its services familiar while introducing additional measures to reasuure guests in a "post-covid world".It sais it has bought market-leading electrostatic fogging machines to fully disinfect all rooms, before they are sealed to ensure no contamination ahead of guest arrival and are introducing a one-way system and mandatory distancing with discreet signs as well as hands-free sanitising stations.Dining will change with a new app removing the need for menus and directories to help offer a contactless dining service and staggered dining services.All front and back of house employees will be provided with PPE and mandatory handwashing every  minutes will be introduced.Norbert Lieder, managing director of ICMI said: ldquoWe are excited to open our properties and give people who have spent several months in the confines of their own home the chance to remember luxury. Yes, the experience will be dferent as the result of our enhanced social distancing requirements, but a stay in one of our properties will be every bit as indulgent as it has always been.ldquoThe measures we have set out are on top of the already mammoth effort it takes to ensure that each destination ndash including castles, centuries-old properties and private islands ndash are ready to welcome guests both old and new as a base to unwind and perhaps rediscover some of the most beautul parts of the country.To check availability and for information on bookings visit www.greywalls.#

title: quietest-times-shop-asda-aldi-tesco-sainsburys
story: As lockdown continues to ease across the UK, analysis provided by Google visiting data has highlightedthebest times for shoppers to head out when less people are in stores.Heres a round-up from the top supermarket chains.AldiAldi stores are more likely to be quieter on weekdays, rather than on weekends.Those wanting to do a quick shop should avoid visiting their storiesat pm on Sundays, when the branches tend to be attheir busiest, with a wait time of up to  minutes expected.The quietest time to shop at Aldi tends to be before am and after pm on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays.AsdaFor shoppers heading to their local Asda store - the busiest days are usually Mondays and Fridays.The data also revealed that shoppers should expect to spend up to  minutes waiting on Mondays, when heading there between am and pm.The quieter days to shop are on Tuesdays, Wednesdays Thursdays and Sundays.SainsburysThose planning on a tripto Sainsburys should head there on Wednesdays, which tend to be the quietest day to shop there.Elsewhere, the busiest days for customers are on Fridays and Saturdays - with a -minute wait time between am and pm on a Friday, and a wait of minutes between pm and pm on a Saturday.TescoIf youre a Tesco shopper, its best to avoid their Express,and Superstores on Monday afternoons.On the other end of the scale, those wanting to carry out their essential shop should head out before midday and after pm on weekdays - as those are the quietest times.Customers can expect to wait up to  minutes between the hours of pm and pm on Saturdays - which tends to be the busiest time of the week.MorrisonsFinally, for those who head to their nearest Morrisons supermarket - best to avoid visiting on Saturdays at noon, with an average wait of up to half an hour.Its also busy in Morrisons on a Friday from pm until pm.The quietest day to go is on a Wednesday.

title: new-bbc-documentary-series-jamie-genevieve-great-indoors-air-week
story: The make-up artist, who is a worldwide star on YouTube and Instagram, will star in the three-part series Jamie Genevieve: Great Indoors on BBC Scotland onThursday at . pm.It comes after the success of her first documentary for the networks BBC Scotland channel Jamie Genevieve #Unfiltered.The former Cathkin High School pupil started out working in make-up counters in Debenhams in Glasgow.Now she is known for her how to make-up demonstrations on YouTube.The new mini-series focuses on how Jamie and husband Jack is coping in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic from trying her hand at hairdressing to baking.

title: list-glasgow-shops-administration-lockdown
story: Here we look at some of the businesses who will no longer be operating in the city and the ones under threat.Remnant KingsCity location: Howard StreetA total of  stafflost their jobs from the firmrsquos bases in Glasgow, Hamilton, and Edinburgh after the administrators were called in.The firm, which started in Glasgow in , said that although they were historically profitable, they have since suffered from declining turnover and trading dficulties in recent years caused by changing consumer habits.:Glasgow firm Remnant Kings goes into admistration resulting in job lossesOasis and Warehouse GroupCity locations past and present: Buchanan Galleries, Silverburn, Princes Square, and Glasgow Fort.The company behind Oasis and Warehouse went into administration in April when Deloitte was appointed as administrator.All stores haveclosed indefinitely whileonline sales have stopped.Reports say the fashion brands have been sold to restructuring business Hilco in a deal which includes stock but not the  stores or  concessions.Hash Ladha, chief executive of Oasis Warehouse, previouslysaid: ldquoThis is a situation that none of us could have predicted a month ago, and comes as shocking and dficult news for all of us.ldquoWe as a management team have done everything we can to try and save the iconic brands that we love.:Oasis and Warehouse who have shops in Glasgow fall into administrationCath KidstonCity location: Gordon StreetCath Kidston said they will not reopen their shops when lockdown ends.They called in the administrators in April with the closure of shops costing around  jobs.It is understood that the owner of the retro fashion brand has secured a deal to buy back the brand and its online operation. This deal, however, does not include shops.BrighthouseCity locations past and present: The Forge Shopping Centre, Paisley Road West, The Lochs Shopping Centre, Easterhouse, Springburn Shopping Centre and Castlemilk Arcade.The rent-to-own retailer went into administration in March. Brighthouse had planned to axe  shops in February in a bid to save the company. But the lockdown measures introduced forced the closure of all stores.It is understood that , employees across the UK will lose their jobs.The company appointed Grant Thornton to keep running thebusiness, and collecting money from customers.The business will still look after customers appliances until their contracts run out.There will be no new rent-to-own sales, and experts said that customers who are claiming compensation from the company might have to wait for longer than usual.Hawkins BazaarCity locations past and present: Glasgow Fort and Buchanan GalleriesThe gt and toy chain went into administration in January putting around  jobs at risk.Trading was suspended from its website and trading was to continue from  stores until lockdown halted that.Moorfields Advisory were asked to take on the role of administrators to seek a rescue deal after the company suffered a challenging Christmas period.Laura AshleyCity location: West George StreetThe future for Laura Ashley remains unclear at the moment after the firm went into administration in March.US-based restructuring company Gordon Brothers bought the chain out of administration in April.The city store remains title: five-alternative-fathers-day-experiences-lockdown
story: A day trip, family get together, a meal at dads favourite might have been on the cards to celebrate Fathers Day, but with our choices restricted this year due to lockdown there are some great alternatives out there.Your dad might be just as happy, or long for, playing a solitary round of golf at his local course or sitting by the riverbank waiting for his catch of the day, but might also want to come together with loved ones to celebrate his special day.From small garden gatherings, to Zoom parties, or virtual museum tours or a local stroll, we bring you the best ideas to make it a Fathers Day to remember.Virtual Museum TourWhile all their museums remain closed due to coronavirus, the National Museum of Scotland have opened their virtual doors for people to enter a world of discovery.Their website gives you the chance to explore their collections and discover more about amazing objects through stories, films, games and resources.There is the chance to delve into our animated adventures and find out more about le in ancient Egypt, learn some Mandarin. Watch videos on a day in the le of an ancient Egyptian priestPriests occupied a unique place in ancient Egyptian society. Find out what they did every day and why in this short animated film. Created for the Discovering Ancient Egypt gallery.There is also the chance to The East Asian CalendarThe East Asian calendar uses a unique system to measure and mark the passing of time. Discover the twelve animals in the calendar and find out what your animal sign is. Created for the East Asia gallery.For more information go to www.nms.ac.uk national-museum-of-scotland If you fancy going a little further afield in your virtual discovery why not take a look at the Louvre in Paris.Activities on offer at the online Louvre include:- One minute in a museum- YouTubers at the Louvre- Mona Lisa VR experience-  years of history- A closer look at Louvre artworksOr you can take a virtual tour of Founding Myths: From Hercules to Darth Vader.The Louvrersquos Petite Galerie first exhibition tells how illustrators, sculptors, painters, puppeteers, filmmakers, and musicians around the world have drawn inspiration from myths, given them form, and brought them to le.Local family walkNow we are allowed to exercise more than once a day and can meet up with another household, a walk near your home could be the ideal gathering.Check out the Ramblers Scotland website to find walks close to home of dfering levels. A great way to enjoy daily local exercise is to try one of their  free mapped Medal Routes short, circular walks in every local authority area in Scotland.Medal Routes are downloadable maps for short, fun circular walks of ,  or  minutes. They are available in every local authority area across Scotland and there are over  walking routes to choose from.The organisation has been working hard to help inspire people to keep active during lockdown - including via through their #RoamSweetHome campaign.If you are giving the Medal Routes a go in your local area during your daily exercise, they are looking for you to share photos or videos from your Medal Route walk by using the #RoamSweetHome hashtag or tagging us on social media.For more information got to www.ramblers.org.uk scotland.aspxGo for a bike rideSales of bikes have soared during lockdown with many shops now having waiting lists after being completely sold out. Transport Secretary Michael Matheson recently confirmed cycling levels are % higher compared with the lockdown baseline, while Cycling Scotlandrsquos automatic cycling counters at  spots around the country revealed remarkable results, with one in Dunfermline recording an increase of % since lockdown.There are a number of family routes to explore without going too far from home. National Cycle Network routes in Scotland run through many areas of outstanding natural beauty, taking in vast forests, iconic castles, shimmering lochs, tranquil glens and spectacular coastlines. The routes provide a unique snapshot of the countryrsquos rich history whilst also connecting all of Scotlands major cities.There are approximately , milesof National Cycle Network routes in Scotland, including  miles of traffic-free routes which use a mix of railway path, canal towpath, forest road, shared-use path, segregated cycle lanes and redetermined rural footways.More information can be found at www.sustrans.org.ukVirtual park discoveryWhile travelling too far afield might just be a distant dream at the moment, we will have to make do with exploring some parts of the great outdoors from our armchairs.Prepare to feel slightly dizzy on the virtual tour for Calornias Yosemite National Park. Virtual Yosemite is a groundbreaking interactive tour of one of Americarsquos most popular and spectacular natural environments. The project is unique in both the depth of its coverage and the quality of its imagery.It was created and photographed by pioneering virtual realityphotographer Scott Highton, who has specialized in VR photography since the early s.Virtual Yosemite allows online visitors to experience over  dferent locations within Yosemite and its surrounding areas, in all seasons. Over  percent of the locations covered are accessible to Yosemite visitors via roads or trails. The deg interactive panoramas are all presented in high resolution, so viewers can zoom in and out to see details, and can pan fully around, including looking upward and downward. Dizzying views from the tops of Yosemitersquos famous clfs and waterfalls are available, along with peaceful locations along trails and in well-known parts of Yosemite Valley.For more information go to www.virtualyosemite.org Closer to home enjoy an aerial view of Loch Lomond National Park under #Lochdown. See the beauty of nature during the coronavirus lochdown through a series of videos which have been posted on their website. Take in the enchanting Loch Achray, a small freshwater loch in the heart of the Trossachs.For more information go to https:www.lochlomond-trossachs.org park-authority lochdown aerial-tours-of-the-national-park Watch a dads favourite movieYou can now watch some streaming services together evenyou are not in the same household and it could be the answer to having a family movie night while social distancing or apart from dad this Fathers Day.Netflix is one example where you can watch the same film together. Netflix Party is a Google Chrome-exclusive extension that only requires one person to install it, making it easy to set up.Once you install it, choose a movie or show, pause it, and then click the red ldquoNP button at the top right of your browser to get a link to a shared session. The extension allows you to chat with everyone in the viewing session, but doesnrsquot allow you to put in a name, so yoursquoll have to remember your friendsrsquo random symbols.Netflix Party allows for full-screen viewing and anybody in the session can hit pause, play or scrub through the timeline.

title: letters-snp-needs-called-account-profligate-spending
story: How much is that per person  Where exactly does it go  These funds come from taxpayers, either iniduals or corporations throughout the entire UK, but the SNP has successfully broken the link between services and taxation in Scotland now. There are many people who believe that most of their services, support, and medication are delivered at no cost, magically appearing from the ether like manna from heaven.They are not costings are just pushed along vertically or horizontally. There are economic, social and environmental limits to everything, except in Scotland apparently.Surely such profligate spending in Scotland by the SNP needs more attention at the moment, not just to refute the SNPrsquos vision of a "milk and honey" independent Scotland but for taxpayers across the UK.David Bone, Girvan.MAY I answer the question put by Liz Galbraithregarding how an independent Scotland would pay for the current crisis An independent Scotland with its own National Bank would do exactly as all other independent countries have done and are doing ndash borrow from their own National Bank, a debt incurred which would never need repaid, as they own that bank. It is simply a strategy for printing money and increasing the supply within the economy, and that is exactly what Westminster is doing.As things stand, as part of the UK, Scotland is not allowed to borrow a single penny from anyone, nor is it allowed to overspend its budget. In fact, it is legally obliged not to spend all its budget, but must end every financial year with a surplus. It is therefore prevented by our membership of the UK from dealing with this crisis as all independent countries around the world are able to. The value of oil, or anything , is totally irrelevant.P Davidson, Falkirk.I NOTE the letter from Liz Galbraith in respect of dferences between New Zealand and Scotland and "extreme financial challenges". I quickly checked a few things and found that GDP per capita in both countries are broadly similar, that Scotland has slightly more people, New Zealand has more land. So how will New Zealand handle those challenges given that they are not any wealthier than Scotland I submit the dference in performance is a combination of constitutional dferences and powers with, perhaps, the luck to have an exceptional leader at the time of crisis. Of course, Scotland may also have had an exceptional leader in Nicola Sturgeon, but without the kind of constitutional powers that Jacinda Ardern has, we may never know.Iain Cope, Glasgow G.RUTH Marrand others are indulging in a fallacy in their assertions that " Scotland was independent..." with regard to the current Covid- pandemic. There is no comparison to be made between Scotland and New Zealand, not least because the latter is an archipelago so biologically remote from the rest of the world and anomalous that it had no terrestrial mammals at all until the Polynesians arrived in the th century.What is more, Scotland voted to stay in the UK in . The choice of two million Scots was the preference for the risks and responsibilities of being part of bigger and more erse country and economy over those of being part of a smaller and narrower one. If we want to play Ms Marrs parlour game and pretend that something  happened, we can also imagine the penury that Scotland would have faced following the greatest economic shock in its history, and wonder how on earth we would have managed with public services stripped of over pound billion every year.Such speculation is all very entertaining, and makes useful material for the attempts of nationalists to distract us from the failings of the SNP Scottish Government. But Scotland is not New Zealand. Nor Norway nor Denmark nor the Republic of Ireland. Nor in terms of responsibility for public health and the NHS and care homes, is it even England.In the real world, we can only judge Nicola Sturgeon and Jeane Freeman and co by the actions and decisions they have taken, and have failed to take, and above all by the Covid- infection rate and death toll in Scotland. No wonder that their supporters want us to be distracted by their pointless fantasies.Peter A Russell, Glasgow G.Read more: Kate Forbes: Expect deep cuts to public services without new powers from Westminster

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  My post-lockdown dream is a scone in a local cafe  What  39 s yours
story: Our nearby garden centre, a well-run operation, insists on hand sanitation before you enter, and sends customers up, down and across the aisles by luminous arrows, asplaying snakes and ladders. If only it were that much fun. Unable to browse without creating a traffic jam, and surrounded by so many masks it could be a dental hygienistsrsquo convention, all pleasure has gone.Now, we are on the cusp of phase two lt-off, scheduled for June . Unless you are in the shielded category, this will allow two households to meet indoors, or socially distanced drinkers and diners to sup in beer gardens and at pavement tables. Home improvers who have been doodling plans for loft conversions can at last call in the Light Brigade.Around the time schools resume in August, itrsquos likely that there will be a widespreadto something approximating normality. In theory at least. The worry is that,the grim weekly supermarket trip offers any guide, the new normal might feel almost as disturbing as our current lockdown. The sight of medicalised faces, half hidden beneath WWII gas masks or snorkels the constant need to self-disinfect ndash a breeding ground surely for a generation of obsessive compulsives the notices and tannoyed reminders that you or others in the vicinity could be unwitting transmitters of a potentially fatal disease ndash none of this is conducive to a sense of relaxation or safety. And yet, unless there is a surge back to our old ways, the economy will slide even further into the abyss. Itrsquos hard not to feel a moral obligation to help businesses get back on their feet.Some weeks ago, I contemplated what I was most looking forward to doing when we emerged from purdah. Apart from meeting family and friends, top of the list was going for a coffee, closely followed by a day in the library. If to this could be added an early evening drink in the pub, possibly planning our next trip to Italy, I would ask nothing more. What a thrilling lestyle, you must be thinking. Yet Irsquom probably not alone, during these eerily frozen weeks, in realising how narrow and predictable the margins of my le are, and happily so.They say it takes six weeks to form a habit, so perhaps we will get used to the protocols protecting us when we enter the classroom, or train, or go shopping for clothes. It might become second nature to dine behind plastic screens on the bistro table, or to stay three steps away from our nearest and dearest, even in their own homes. And in one respect at least Irsquom looking forward to making my own mask. In winter I resemble a figure in a John Bellany painting, my nose ice cold and red raw. A fleecy face-covering could save on central heating.Even as the danger of infection diminishes, the sobering reality is that fear will persist for a considerable time. To expect to gather in a cafe as we used to, drawing up chairs to crowd around a table, is to day-dream. Almost nothing will be the same as in the good old days, or at least not at first. In the months ahead we will either have to accustom ourselves to new and uncomfortable regulations and rules, or stay housebound.Therersquos little doubt, though, that seeing the ties that bind us being slowly slackened is a huge psychological boost. As yoursquoll have guessed, Irsquom not Melrosersquos answer to Marco Polo. When Ryanairrsquos engines begin to roar, it wonrsquot be me yoursquoll see in the duty free. Yet the mere fact of being banned from travelling more than five miles from home is what has felt so constricting in recent times, even , like me, yoursquore usually quite happy staying within easy walking distance of your door.As we go through the gradual phases of our staggered release, like a barge inching through a lock, simply knowing that we can go wherever we like will come as a tremendous relief. Who careswe must be home by bedtime  Just glimpsing somewhere dferent will be excitement enough. It marks the restoration of a basic human liberty. And, as our leash ens, so spirits will lt. The invisible cordon sanitaire that has been restraining us in will vanish, and to a large degree our lives will feel like our own again.Yet while we yearn to get back to our old haunts, elements of the crisis have shown a better way, which hopefully will endure. The rise in walking and cycling signals a serious cultural sht. Along with the upturn in home deliveries, it might indicate the beginning of the end for the car. Even where I live, in the country, the air is cleaner, the roads emptier, the birds louder. The outpouring of care and concern shown across the nation for neighbours and those in need has strengthened peoplersquos connection to their community. More of us have been shopping or ordering locally, and discovering whatrsquos on our doorstep. Some have been baking their own bread, or cooking from scratch, and discovering the humdrum but satisfying joys of home le. Looking to the uncertain future, a few are on their way to becoming self-sufficient.As we gradually emerge into a freer existence, carrying hand sanitisers the way Clint Eastwood holstered a Colt , one thing seems certain. We wonrsquot take anything for granted again. The simplest of activities have already assumed a profound signicance. To call something ordinary or normal will soon be the highest terms of praise. I never thought a weekend Americano in our nearest cafe would be a red-letter day. Add to that the possibility ndash oh the glamour! ndash of a cheese and chive scone and there, on a plate, is proof of how wonderful le can be.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald

title: americas-rabble-rouser-chief-heads-back-road
story: Then came a clue to the man who was behind the curtain cranking out the material: ldquoMAKE AMERICA GREAT AGAIN.Having tried out other campaign slogans for size on Twitter, the President of the US went back to where it all began.It is an understandable impulse when nothing  seems to work. If there was a button marked ldquoreset, many millions of Americans might rush to press it. Erase the last four years, months, weeks, days, hours. Restore Americarsquos factory settings, because something has gone catastrophically awry.The duff sloganeering was not the worst offence the President committed on Twitter. By many a mile that title went to his musings on Martin Gugino, the -year-old who was shoved by police during a protest in Buffalo, New York, over the death of George Floyd.Mr Gugino fell, cracking his head, and as his blood poured on to the pavement the police walked on by. The incident was captured on video. Two policeman have been charged.The presidentrsquos take on this  Mr Gugino ldquocould be a hard left ldquoprovocateur who was carrying a scanner to block out police communications . ldquoI watched, said Mr Trump. ldquohe fell harder than he was pushed. Was aiming scanner. Could be a set up Mr Guginorsquos lawyer called this a ldquoa dark, dangerous and untrue accusation. If you wanted a response red hot with fury one could turn to Andrew Cuomo, the Governor of New York. He thought nothing the President might say on Twitter could surprise him any more. He was wrong. ldquoHow reckless, he said of the Gugino accusation. ldquoHow irresponsible. How mean. How crude. If there was ever a reprehensible, dumb comment hellip and this from the President of the US. Earlier, Mr Cuomo summed up the bewilderment of many when he asked simply, ldquoHow did we get to this place Good question, depressing answers. The appalling treatment of African-Americans did not start with Mr Trump. Nor was he responsible for a virus that has cruelly laid bare the failings of the country, not least in healthcare, and the inequalities that persist.: Letters - leave the statuesBut as the President that famous buck has to stop with him. It would be a test of even the greatest American leader at any time. One can only wonder what a Johnson, or an FDR, would do. That it falls to Mr Trump to act, and in an election year, lays the ground for troubled times to come.It has been a politically disastrous couple of weeks for the President. The events and images have been shocking. A man dying in the street at the hands of police. Peaceful protestors being tear-gassed and beaten so their commander-in-chief could walk from the White House and hold a bible aloft. A security fence erected in front of the White House, something that was not necessary during the worst civil unrest of the s. Threatening to use soldiers against lawful protesters, and being castigated by a former Defence Secretary for doing so. Tales of a president fleeing to a White House bunker. All of it dreadful, much of it used against America by its opponents.Even Mr Trump, a man who never met a setback he did not try to spin, has had trouble ignoring the plummeting poll ratings that have resulted. In a CNN poll published on Monday, % disapproved of his performance as president, with % approving. Those are the kind of numbers Jimmy Carter and fellow one term President George HW Bush racked up.Overall, the incumbent is  points behind his Democratic challenger, Joe Biden. In what should be further cause for alarm, Mr Trumprsquos support among white voters without degrees is falling, and his problem with women has grown worse. In  he was  points behind with women voters. A recent poll put him  points behind.As ever with the defensive Mr Trump, his instinct is to go on the attack. That could signal more sackings, more likely it will mean getting back on the rally circuit, the place he feels comfortable and wanted.His supporters argue the Black Lives Matter protests, which brought hundreds of thousands on to the streets, are a green light for the Trump rallies to restart. The president has suggested the first event could even be as soon as next week. This at a time when , Americans have died from Covid-, and when the White House infectious diseases adviser, Dr Anthony Fauci, has warned the pandemic ldquoisnrsquot over yet.: The truth about Scotlands slaving pastJust when the US might benefit from devoting its considerable energies into tackling its policing and race relations crises, or even simply pausing for a period of reflection after a dreadful start to the year, the President will in effect be firing the starting gun in the race to the White House.Judging by their advertising, both sides will be using the recent protests to boost their arguments. Mr Trump knows it worked for Richard Nixon in , but he was not the incumbent. It is a tactic fraught with danger in as much as it risks fuelling further tension and ision, the last thing the country needs.We know from past experience the kind of candidate Mr Trump becomes when he fronts one of his rallies. Crowds chanting for Hillary Clinton to be locked up, the mocking of a disabled reporter, the harassment of the press his rallies in the run up to the  election set a sour tone for his presidency from the off. Who will be the scapegoats this time Mr Trump could do with some wise counsel at this point, but that looks in desperately short supply, not least from his own party. Too many Republican candidates are afraid to criticise Mr Trump lest his base turns against them. But as of now he has shown himself unwilling to listen to anyone .Whatever campaign slogan he settles on, Mr Trump will doubtless position himself as the man to save America. Who will save America from Mr Trump is the question his Republican colleagues should be asking themselves.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions.
