Photo: PA WireArticle  of the Detention of TerroristsOrder  authorises a secretary of state, minister of state or under secretary of state to sign an ICO. As minister of state, I was one of the ministers authorised by that order to sign, and thus to make, ICOs. The Supreme Court’s judgment does not say which minister of state signed the ICO in relation to Gerry Adams. As I say, it may be that my signature was on some of the ICOs made in this period, although they could have been signed by David Windlesham or Paul Channon. Most likely, they would have been signed by David Windlesham as he was specically assigned by Mr Whitelaw to oversee security issues, although we all worked together as a team on all aspects of Northern Ireland’s administration. I note that it was David Windlesham who on  December  moved the motion in the House of Lords that the  Order be approved. He remarked then that “applications for interim custody orders are by no means automatically granted by the secretary of state.Lord Kerr of Tonaghmore, a Justice of the Supreme Court of the UK and former Lord Chief Justice in Northern Ireland, who read out the unanimous judgement in the Gerry Adams case. Photo: Supreme Court PA WireThere is a thorough process of scrutiny before he, or anyone on his behalf, decides whether or not to sign one at all.”It is clear to me that the Supreme Court has misinterpreted the nature and scope of the  Order. The court misunderstands the signicance of Article , which specically provided for a minister of state or undersecretary of state to sign an ICO in the name of the secretary of state.This provision was understood by government in making the order and in exercising it, and by Parliament in the debates about whether to approve the order, to authorise the minister of state or under secretary of state to decide whether an ICO should be made. In so doing, weacted in the name of the secretary of state, who was responsible for the Northern Ireland Officeand the ministerial team and who was, of course, closely involved in many ICO decisions himself, as well as directing which ministers should oversee which aspects of Northern Ireland’s administration.The fundamental failure of the Supreme Court’s judgment is its total misunderstanding of the nature of ministerial and departmental government and methods of operating. A junior minister on duty at Stormont is in effect the persona of Her Majesty’s government and is thereby empowered to act for and as the secretary of state in the latter’s absence. And the secretary of state was often unavoidably absent. In relation to Northern Ireland, it was inherent in the nature of direct rule that the secretary of state had to be frequently in London – in Parliament or the cabinet – and that his responsibilities would often have to be exercised by a junior minister on the ground.On the weekends, one of us was always the duty minister. One minister always had to be available to Parliament, including to answer urgent questions. And those of us who were members of the House of Commons had also toto London frequently to vote .When the order was made, on  November , and when it was approved by Parliament in December , it was certainly contemplated that there would often be cases in which an ICO would need to be made by the minister of state or under secretary of state rather than by the secretary of state himself. The order clearly provides for this to happen. The high number of ICOs that the government anticipated would have to be made, and were in practice made, also helps explain why the order provides that junior ministers may order temporary detention. The Supreme Court’s assertion that it would not have been dficult for the secretary of state to consider each case personally and to make each ICO himself simply does not match the reality.As it happens, almost all signing of ICOs, where the actual signing of the document took place in Stormont Castle, was discussed directly with other ministers and usually with the secretary of state by telephone or message,he had to be in London or his constituency home in Penrith.The secretary of state could not always be directly involved and even when involved in some cases it would often be the minister of state or under secretary of state, in Stormont, who had reviewed the grounds for making an ICO in detail and who was satisfied that an ICO should be made.The minister on duty in Stormont was fully entitled to act in the secretary of state’s name. Other ministers were consulted, to the extent possible, not because this was what the law required, asthe junior minister were simply the mouthpiece of the secretary of state , but because that is how any team of ministers, operating as a team, would act in relation to important matters with political implications for which the secretary of state would have to accept constitutional responsibility.In any case, in relation to Gerry Adams one can be absolutely sure that it would have been discussed most fully and confirmed by the secretary of state before the ICO was made.The political salience and security implications of detaining Mr Adams would have made this unavoidable.I do not know whether there is a record of the secretary of state’s involvement in this case or any other case in which his signature does not appear on the ICO itself. The Supreme Court’s judgment implies not.This may be unsurprising in view of how ICOs were often made, which is to say by a minister of state or under secretary of state in Stormont, with the secretary of state often consulted by message or telephone from London or Penrith, but without a record of that involvement necessarily being kept or now being available. There would have been no reason, and perhaps no capacity, to record the secretary of state’s personal involvement, save in those cases where he himself signed the ICO, because Article  authorised the minister of state to sign the ICO and this signature had itself to be sufficient to authorise detention on the ground in Northern Ireland.But it is a travesty to conclude that because ministers complied with the terms of the  Order, and did not go above and beyond it to somehow record the secretary of state’s involvement, the ICO must now be quashed and the detention ruled unlawful.It is quite startling to see the Supreme Court reasoning that the prosecution had failed in Gerry Adams’s case to prove that the secretary of state had personally authorised his detention. The shape of the  Order makes very clear that an ICO signed by a minister of state or snder secretary of state is the same as an ICO signed by the secretary of state himself and authorises detention. It would have been utterly unworkable for the Royal Ulster Constabulary to have refused to detain suspected terrorists unless and until proof had been provided that an ICO signed by the minister had also been personally considered by the secretary of state. Or for commissioners determining whether there should be continuing detention to have held that they did not have jurisdiction unless and until the secretary of state had provided evidence that he had personally considered whether to make the ICO in question.This would have made the scheme of the  Order simply unworkable. The Supreme Court’s reading of the  Order was not what government intended, or understood, or what Parliament approved. The whole point of the signature requirement in Article  is to make clear who is authorised to make an ICO and thus whose signature on the face of an ICO makes it lawful to detain the person in question.The making of ICOs in -, which the Supreme Court has now denounced as unlawful, was entirely in line with the law, with the wishes of Parliament, with normal ministerial practice and with the immediate security needs of protecting the public from acts of appalling violence and bloodshed . Like Professor Ekins and Sir Stephen, I take the case for legislation to overturn the effect of the Supreme Court’s judgment – to make clear that ICOs signed by a minister of state or under secretary of state were lawful — to be overwhelming. In so legislating, Parliament would be reaffirming its clear, obvious and original intentions and the absolutely normal practices of departmental governance and ministerial responsibility.• Lord Howell of Guildford is the last surviving member of the ministerial team in the Northern Ireland Office, with responsibility under the Detention of TerroristsOrder . He served as minister of state for Northern Ireland from - and as secretary of state for Energy and then for Transport under Margaret Thatcher. He was elected to the House of Commons as an MP in  and has sat in the Lords as a Conservative Le peer since . He was minister of state in the Foreign Office from  to • Morning View: Lord Howell’s paper reiterates need for MPs to make clear the legal position on internment• Other reactions to the Supreme Court ruling below• Prof Ekins: A summary of the Policy Exchange paper• Trevor Ringland: Supreme Court ruling on Adams walked on graves of judges murdered by IRA• Jeffrey Dudgeon: Supreme Court ruling on Adams didn’t reflect violent context of the time• Doug Beattie: Time has come for an inquiry into Sinn Fein, and their relationships with the IRA• Jim Allister: We should be told why anyone thought that Adams was deserving of legal aid• Brian John Spencer: If we are to stop the rewriting of history, we need to say what IRA did during internment• Kenny Donaldson: Victims of terror are dismayed by the Supreme Court ruling• Morning View: A devastating analysis of the Supreme Court’s ruling in the Gerry Adams case• Letter: There is little prospect of trials of republicans• Letter: Many of us in England would help fund civil cases against terrorists——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: welsh government resilience plan supports education over s
story: The plan helps ensure that learners are supported throughout the coronavirus pandemic.It is aimed at education for learners aged  and over, including further and higher education, apprenticeships, employability and adult learning.The plan identies the priority groups most in need of support and sets out the expectations of how education providers and the Welsh Government will work together in response to covid- and how key decisions will be communicated.Since education providers in Wales closed for face-to-face learning on March , colleges and universities have moved to remote learning, delivering online lectures, tutorials and reviews, as well as ensuring support for more vulnerable learners continues.The plan is ided into three phases ndash the current lsquorescuersquo phase is focused on ensuring education providers have immediate security of funding and arrangements for learning in place this academic year the lsquoreviewrsquo phase plans for potential changes this autumn and the lsquorenewrsquo phase will put arrangements in place for the remainder of the academic year -.The plan identies learners for whom the coronavirus is likely to cause the most disruption, including Year  and , and vocational learners who need to access colleges or workplaces to complete their courses.The Welsh Government has increased online resources for post- through its Hwb , with distance learning resources available for both learners and providers.The Resilience Plan follows the publication of the continuity of learning plan for schools, lsquoStay Safe. Stay Learningrsquo, published last month.Education minister Kirsty Williams has also announced that pound.m of capital funding, part of the Secircr Cymru programme, will be used to invite applications from Welsh universities to submit novel research proposals that could contribute to or boost the advancement of research that impacts covid-.Ms Williams said: ldquoThe coronavirus has presented huge challenges for both students and education providers, in both the immediate and the longer term.ldquoThis Resilience Plan will provide a clear focus so we can work together with our education partners to overcome these challengesldquoThis plan will complement our continuity of learning plan for schools, lsquoStay Safe. Stay Learningrsquo, but recognises the greater levels of autonomy and ersity of education and training provided by the post- sector.ldquoOur colleges, universities and training providers are critical to the national response to the coronavirus and the rebuilding of the economy. We are committed to doing all we can to support them.Minister for economy, transport and North Wales, Ken Skates said: ldquoWe do not only want to bounce back from this pandemic, but to build back better by creating a national economy which sees employment, wealth and prosperity sp equally across Wales.ldquoThe post- education sector will be crucial to this.ldquoAs we shape our recovery from the impacts of coronavirus, we are committed to doing all we can to provide a strong foundation for those looking for employment, learners, trainees and apprentices to flourish in the future.ldquoThis incredibly challenging period has already highlighted the talent, commitment and incredible resilience of training and learning providers in supporting iniduals here in Wales.ldquoItrsquos efforts like these that will help ensure we emerge from this crisis stronger than ever. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new app provide specialist advice gps seconds
story: The Consultant Connect app has been fast-tracked for use in NHS Wales to help deal with the covid- outbreak and support primary care in the long term to offer better advice and guidance to patients.By accessing speedy advice the new app will help prevent unnecessary hospital admissions and referrals and ensure that those needing hospital treatment are managed accordingly.The core service, being rolled out across Wales, gives clinicians access to specialists in respiratory medicine, cardiology, diabetes, palliative care and acute medicine for covid.Health Boards can also add access to a range of local advice that is appropriate to their patientsrsquo needs.A GP or other clinician accesses the service either by dialling a phone number or using the Consultant Connect app.After choosing a speciality from a menu they are connected with a specialist in an average of  seconds.Mr Gething said: ldquoI am very pleased we are able to start rolling out the Consultant Connect in NHS Wales."This will help to support primary care to determine the right treatment for their patients.ldquoRight now it will save crucial time for health care professionals and reduce the amount of hospital visits needed by patients, at a time when our NHS is facing extra pressure.ldquoIn the long-term the use of this technology is an important part of our plan for the future of health and social care,"A Healthier Wales."Making the most of technology is vital to us building a modern health and social care service, in which care is delivered closer to home. article_url   content_id down, and what a glittering opening evening it must have been as the audience wore evening dress.The review featured next day read, ldquoBrilliant Initial Performance.More newsVale council issues warning over the use of parksFines increased for coronavirus lockdown breachesMarie Curie Great Blooming Tea Party goes virtualA few years later in , the drama section came into being and with it a new title of the Penarth Operatic  Dramatic Society, known affectionately as PODS.Since then PODS has progressed down through the decades with many highlights along the way.One being in  when PODS presented that great musical, The King And I, which won the premier prize at the Waterford International Festival, for which the company received a beautul Waterford crystal vase.The Town Council held a reception to honour the Society at the Paget Rooms, and James Callaghan, the local MP, paid his tribute to PODS saying it ldquoadded lustre and brought culture to Penarth.Another landmark was the play, Dear Octopus, by Dodie Smith produced for PODS th anniversary celebrations.One of our most challenging and exciting shows was Cabaret in , which won the National Operatic  Dramatic Associationrsquos award for Best Production and Best Stage Management and Technical presentation.More recently in , to honour and pay tribute to the many men who gave their lives in World War One, PODS presented the very special play, Last Man Standing, which also won a NODA award for Best Drama.In , PODS decided to do pantomime, and this has been a greatly gratying and popular addition to the companyrsquos output.Itrsquos wonderful to see children in the cast having on-stage experience, and then those children in the audience, perhaps for the first time, enjoying and loving live theatre.PODS is a very busy Society putting on four shows a year, a musical, two plays and a pantomime.Mrs Gardner said: ldquoThis year, sadly and very upsettingly after much hard work by all involved, the covid- virus struck as PODS had just set-up at the Paget Rooms ready for its run of Goodnight Mister Tom, only to be told the venue would be shut down next day.ldquoSince January, the Society had also been rehearsing for its May musical, The Full Monty, and that too has had to be cancelled.       ,params: .pushldquoNevertheless, when this terrible emergency is over the company will put on these two productions sometime in the future. ldquoPODS is proud of its achievement in giving much pleasure and entertainment to the local community with its first-class shows over the last  years, and its goal is to make its centenary in  with the help of its faithful audiences, friends and patrons.PODS is always ready to welcome new members, but at the moment it cannot meet or rehearse story: Pictures and videos appeared on social media on Monday of groups of people sitting on the benches along the seafront, and groups of people gathering along the front.Currently, lockdown measures household.South Wales Police did not discloseany people had been issued with a fine for breaking lockdown, but a spokesman said ldquoOur approach is to engage, explain and encourage people to follow the regulations.ldquoWe only apply [a Fixed Penalty Notice] as a last resort.ldquoItrsquos a matter for the inidual to ensure they follow the regulations.Some Penarth residents said they were concerned by the number of people along the seafront on Monday.Melanie Regan, , said she didnrsquot feel safe to walk along the seafront with her husband due to the number of people there.ldquoIt is s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentTHE RNLI in Wales has reacted to the Welsh Governmentrsquos plans for easing lockdown with an important safety warning.The Governmentrsquos changes, from Monday, June , will limit people to staying local and not generally travel more than five miles to reduce the risk of the coronavirus spreading.People from two dferent households in the same local area will be permitted to meet up as long as they are outdoors, and they maintain strict social distancing.The lesaving charity has called for the public to stay safe.RNLI lesaving manager, Matt Crofts said: ldquoAfter a warm spring coupled with the easing of a lockdown which has seen many of us unable to visit our local beaches, we expect many people to be eager to hit the coast.ldquoThe changes to Government guidance does not mean our coasts are safe.ldquoThe dangers that have always been there remain.ldquoWe ask those who are local to beaches to continue to be aware of the inherent dangers.ldquoOur strong advice to the Welsh public, who are not local to a beach, is to follow the Welsh Government guidance to meet outdoors and exercise locally and not to travel to the coast.ldquoAir temperatures may be warming up but the sea temperature remains consistently chilly all year, jumping or falling into cold water or spending longer periods than normal submerged in the water can lead to, potentially fatal, cold water shock.Water safety lead for the RNLI in Wales, Chris Cousens urged people to remember the safety advice.He said: ldquoStay in familiar surroundings and follow the Welsh Government advice.ldquoDo not put yourself, your family and emergency services at risk by taking risks or assuming it lsquowonrsquot happen to yoursquo.ldquoIf you do see someone at risk call  and ask for the coastguard.A high proportion of calls for the RNLI in Wales are to those who have been to people cut off by the tide, including during the lockdown period.Some parts of Wales have among the highest tidal range in Europe.A beach that was clear yesterday at pm might be completely covered in sea at the same time today.Mr Cousens said: ldquoIf you are heading out for a coastal walk, make sure it is safe before you go.ldquoAlways check the tide times and conditions before you set off and while out, be aware of your surroundings and keep an eye on the tide direction.ldquoAsk for local advice and look out for safety signs.ldquoAlways carry a means of calling for help and know to call  and ask for the coastguardyou or someone  is at risk.The RNLI is working to start a leguard service on several beaches in Wales and is in discussion with the Welsh Government, local authorities, landowners, and other partners.At present there are no RNLI leguards on beaches in Wales. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey Sian from the MS Society Cymru said: ldquoThis really is an amazing donation and your support will allow us to continue to provide vital services for people affected by MS and to invest in groundbreaking medical research."To top off the evening of celebration the girls surprised everyone with some jaw-dropping performances by the incredible Valley Boys, a professional tribute act of west end singers dedicated to the Jersey Boys. but hopefully not for much longer.ldquoWhen the government announced all businesses were to close to protect society due to the covid- pandemic, it raised a lot of distress and uncertainty for many go-ahead is given for the business to re-open.All existing and new clients will be assured of the usual warm welcome to the salon that previously existed.Both therapists have completed the Barbicide perspex screens in treatment rooms for those clients who attend regularly for nail appointments.Masks will be worn at all times and clients will be offered a cleaning station for handwashing, which However, the charity is also keen to stress that not all older people are fortunate enough to have family and friends and thatrsquos why the work of Age Connects is so vital, even more so now.Nona Hexter, who runs the charityrsquos Senior Health Shop on Holton Road in Barry said: ldquoFor so many years we have been here for older people to pop in for information, advice and have a cuppa and chat with their friends and us too."It is tough not being able to be there in person for all of the vulnerable older people that we know but staff and volunteers are ensuring we are still here at the end of the phone, helping with shopping and in any way we can within safety guidelines.Karen Steele from Age Connects said: ldquoIn the first seven weeks of lockdown, we received , incoming calls for information, advice and support and in almost all cases we have managed to provide support or signpost people onwards."The charity is urging the general public and local businesses to ldquohelp us help to keep older people safe, well and reassured at this dficult time by making a donation to support its work at grass roots level where it is making a vital dference.A donation of just pound will s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentCHANGES to advice for people shielding from coronavirus are being introduced from Monday, June .People who have been shielding can now take exercise outdoors and meet people from another household, as long as it takes place outdoors.There are two changes to the advice for this group.Outdoor exercise is unlimited, as long as iniduals strictly follow social distancing rules and hygiene practices.Those who are shielding can meet outside with people from another household ndash but should not go into another personrsquos house or share food with them.Welsh Government minister for health and social services, Vaughan Gething announced the changes on Sunday, May .There are no other changes being made to the advice for those who are shielding at this stage.People who are shielding should continue to follow all the other advice previously given.They should not go shopping or attend work outside of home.They should continue to have food and medicine delivered to them.This advice comes from chief medical officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton.He said: ldquoRisk can never be completely eliminated but we advise those shielding to exercise at times that are less busy, so the risk of contact with others is reduced.ldquoWe have advised everyone in Wales to maintain social distance of two metres and keep good hygiene when meeting outdoors."For those who are shielding, strictly following these rules is vital.Mr Gething said: ldquoI am pleased that so many have been shielding so diligently ndash not only protecting themselves but also helping to protect our NHS.ldquoWe recognise how challenging these last few months, with minimal face-to-face contact with others, has been.ldquoI am incredibly proud of all those who have and continue to provide the vital support to enable people to shield.ldquoOur local authority partners, pharmacies, volunteers, and major food retailers have all pulled together to make shielding possible.The chief medical officer is continuing to develop his advice for shielding people after June .All who are shielding will receive a letter from Dr Atherton in the coming fortnight setting out the next steps. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey shielding so diligently ndash not only protecting themselves but also helping to protect our NHS.ldquoWe recognise how challenging these last few months, with minimal face-to-face contact with others, has been.ldquoI am incredibly proud of all those who have and continue to provide the vital support to enable people to shield.ldquoOur local authority partners, pharmacies, volunteers, and major food retailers have all pulled together to make shielding possible.The chief medical officer is continuing to develop his advice for shielding people after June .All who are shielding will receive a letter from Dr Atherton in the coming fortnight setting out the next steps. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey title: contact tracing system wales rolled out
story: From today, anyone who has a positive coronavirus test result will be contacted by a team of contact tracers and asked for details of everyone they have had close contact with while they have had symptoms.Close contact means anyone who has been within m of and had a face-to-face-conversation, had skin-to-skin contact with or have coughed on, or been in other forms of contact with for a minute or longer.It also means they have been within m of for more than  minutes or they have travelled in a vehicle with or sat near on public transport.All these close contacts will be followed up and will be asked to self-isolate for  days as a precaution to prevent the virus spreading further.From Monday, June  contact tracing will be supported by a new online system, which will give people the option to provide details of their close contacts electronically.Mr Gething said: ldquoTodayrsquos roll-out of the contact tracing element of our Test, Trace, Protect strategy is a signicant step forward in the gradual move out of lockdown.ldquoOver the last few months, thanks to the help of the public and the way they have followed the stay-at-home rules, we have managed to slow the spread of the virus to the point where we can today ease the regulations to enable family and friends to meet again.ldquoContact tracing is a tried and tested method of bringing outbreaks of infectious diseases under control and we hope it will do the same with coronavirus ndash but for it to be successful, we need everyonersquos help and cooperation in sharing details about their movements and contacts."We also need people to self-isolatethey may be at risk.ldquoThe scientic advice is clear ndash we need a contact tracing system in place before we begin to lt restrictions further.Health boards and local authorities are working together to deliver contact tracing.The system has been trialled in four health board areas over the last two weeks and more than  contact tracers have so far been employed.This number is likely to rise as the system is rolled out.Testing capacity has been increased to support contact tracing and home tests and tests at the drive-through centres for both critical workers and the public can be booked online.Full details of the contact tracing system are available at gov.wales testing-coronavirus article_url   content_id   site_id title: meet environment author stephen moss penarth bookstore online event
story: Mr Moss will talk to bookshop owner Mel Grfin about his new book, The Accidental Countryside, before taking questions from the virtual audience.This online event will take place at pm on Wednesday, June  via Zoom conference call.More storiesPopular book club moves online to adapt to isolationGrfin Books nominated for Best Independent Bookshop AwardIndependent bookshop to host crime author Matt JohnsonWhat links Britainrsquos Iron Age hill forts and urban skyscrapers Churchyards and docklands Golf courses and gravel pits Together, they make up The Accidental Countryside.Wherever you go in Britain ndash in the city, town, or countryside ndash you come across hidden havens for wildle.They may be home to sand lizards and stoats, adders and orchids, water voles and peregrine falcons.In The Accidental Countryside, Mr Moss tells the fascinating and uplting story of how wildle has taken advantage of us ndash often when we least expected it.He also asks a crucial question: without these places, will Britainrsquos wildle be able to survive Mr Moss is a lelong naturalist, broadcaster and author.His books include The Twelve Birds of Christmas, Wild Kingdom: Bringing Back Britainrsquos Wildle and The Wren: A Biography. title: schools wales urged open august holidays
story: An announcement on the re-opening of schools is expected this week, having been closed to the vast majority of pupils since March , with local authorities being told that at least three weeks notice will be provided,But despite the scheduled summer holidays set to start in mid July, leaving only approximately three weeks of lessons at most,the National Education UnionCymru claims that plans for the six week break to be brought forward a month had been abandoned.More NewsDeaths in Vale of Glamorgan jump  per cent higher in AprilBarry Dock and Penarth leboats seventh launch to tide stranded people on Sully IslandMeet environment author Stephen Moss at Penarth bookstore online eventUnion secretaryDavid Evans, in a Facebook post, said that such a move would result in a -week term in the autumn with just a one-week break in the middle for the teachers, adding that thiswould mean breaking summer arrangements and resulting ldquocontractual issues, describing such plans as a ldquonon-starter.But Arfon MS Sian Gwenllian says thatbringing this yearrsquos summer holidays forward should continue to be ldquofully explored, suggesting a phased and gradual re-opening of schools in August rather than September, but onlyit was safe to do so.Plaid Cymrursquos education spokesperson claims there could beldquoeducational advantages in bringing forward the start of the autumn term.This, she added, could further pave the way for permanent changesand a re-configuring of the traditionalthree term year in a way that would be ldquoless disjointed andmore in tune with modern-day needs.ldquoThe educational advantages of bringing this yearrsquos summer holidays forward and beginning the autumn term in August should continue to be fully explored, she said.ldquoBefore the Coronavirus crisis there were on-going discussions about school term s and the need to change from three to four school terms and making the summer holidays shorter.ldquoWith need to re-visit those discussions in the wake of Coronavirus and now may be the time to consider changing school terms permanently and toreconfigurethe annual school pattern.She added that the current practice ofldquointense half terms followed by a short holiday has caused both teachers and pupils to become tired, claiming that many teacherssay that the summer term is ldquotoo long ndash especiallyfor children who are not supported with their learning at home.She concluded,ldquoAt the moment in Wales, terms are of dferent swith holidays coming irregularlyand yet research shows that continuity and progression are importantelements of learning.ldquoMany teacherssay that the summer term is too long, with the first few weeks of the autumn term being used for catch-up, especiallyfor children who are not supported with their learning at home.ldquoIn the meantime, we must crucially continue to refine remote learning. This should be central to the plans for the gradual re-opening of schools. It should also be integral to future planning too as we continue to strive to close the digital poverty ide and the attainment gap.ldquoThe focus of our education system must be on engaging with every pupil and ensuring no child is left behind.A Welsh Government spokesperson said: ldquoThe Welsh Government is working closely with unions, local authorities, scientists and education staff to decide on the next steps for education in Wales and the Minister intends to update further this week. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: check catch prepare summer september   wales schools enter next phase
story: Education minister Kirsty Williams MS says all schools will start the next phase on Monday, June , with the term extended by a week, therefore ending on Monday, July .In the next academic year, beginning in September, the intention is that the autumn half-term break will be expanded to two weeks.In each school there will be a phased approach.More storiesWelsh Government education minister Kirsty Williams sets out thinking on schools Welsh Government provides schools with new mental health supportSchools in Wales will remain closed on June , announces education minister Kirsty WilliamsYear groups will be split into cohorts with staggered starts, lessons, and breaks.This will mean, at most, a third of pupils present at any one time, though schools may need time to reach this level of operation.There will be much smaller classes, providing secure dedicated time with teachers and classmates.This time will include online and personalised classroom experience, getting children and teachers ready for a similar experience in September.Next week, the Welsh Government will publish guidance to support schools, as well as further and higher education institutions.This will include information on managing their facilities and logistical arrangements, including buildings, resources, cleaning and transport.The Government is also publishing a paper from its covid- Technical Advisory Group, representing the latest understanding of the virus with respect to children and education.Further Education colleges are ensuring that appropriate measures are being taken to re-open for face-to-face learning from Monday, June .They will prioritise those students requiring licence to practice assessments and vulnerable learners.This follows close working with government and the joint trade unions.Guidance for childcare providers will also be published in the next week, supporting them to increase the numbers of children in attendance alongside schools.Ms Williams said her announcement gave schools three and a half weeks to continue preparing for the next phase.She said: ldquoWe will use the last weeks of the summer term to make sure pupils, staff and parents are prepared ndash mentally, emotionally and practically ndash for the new normal in September.ldquo June means there will have been one full month of test, trace and protect, which will continue to expand.ldquoI can also announce that teachers will be a priority group in our new antibody-testing programme.ldquoAs we continue to keep Wales safe, this approach will be critical.ldquoThe evolving science suggests that warm weather and sunlight gives us the best opportunity to ensure more time in school.       ,params: .pushldquoWaiting until September would mean almost half a year without schooling.ldquoThat would be to the detriment to the wellbeing, learning progress and mental health of our young people.ldquoThis is and has been a worrying period for us all.ldquoI know that many will feel apprehensive.ldquoWe have not rushed this work and this decision.ldquoThe three-and-a-half-week period before the next phase also gives us time to keep watch on developments where and provides further check-points to review evidence and the roll-out of testing.ldquoThis is the best practical option that meets my five principles which underpin my decision making.ldquoI am also convinced that it is only by ing to their own school that we will see increased attendance from our more vulnerable and disadvantaged children.ldquoWorking together we will secure equity and excellence for pupils as they check in, catch up, and prepare for summer and September. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey the coronavirus pandemic in March this year.The drive thru in the Ty Verlon estate-based store is located near the roundabout which provides access to and from Wenvoe, Cardf, Dinas Powys, Sully, and Penarth.Other drive thrus to re-open include the Cardf stores at Culverhouse Cross, Excelsior Road, Cardf Bay, Longwood Drive, and Newport Road.Extensive queues formed when two drive thru reopened in Pencoed, Bridgend, on Tuesday, June .A McDonaldrsquos spokeswoman said: "This is only possible following the hard work of the teams in our  pilot restaurants."Our employees, franchisees and suppliers have worked tirelessly to implement new procedures to enable safe working so that we can now help all parts of the UK and Ireland to enjoy theof the Big Mac."With fewer employees working in our kitchens and service areas, our teams will still need your patience and support as they continue to adjust to the new ways of working."Face coverings, gloves, perspex screens and new safety and hygiene processes mean it will look dferent, it will take a little longer and as we have seen in the pilot restaurants, we expect demand will be high."Please bear with us, we will continue to put our people first ndash their safety is our priority."She added: "In the last week, on occasion, we have taken the decision to close drive thru lanes where demand has impacted local communities or the safety of our people or customers.""We will continue to work with local authorities and the police as we extend our reopening plans."With smaller teams, we will still be offering a limited menu over title: shielding continue   people wales
story: Shielding continues for all generations" Shielding to continue for , people in WalesA general view of a close up of the hands of an elderly woman at home.." Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentALMOST , people will this week start receiving a letter from the chief medical Officer for Wales setting out the latest advice to protect them from coronavirus.They will be asked to continue shielding until Sunday, August , but the letter will also describe how the medical advice has changed to enable them to go outdoors to meet other people for the first time since the start of the pandemic.The shielded group are people who are classed as extremely vulnerable to developing serious illnessthey contract coronavirus because they have a specic health condition.They have been following strict shielding advice for  weeks.MORE STORIES"Check in, Catch up, Prepare for summer and September" - Wales schools to enter next phaseContact tracing system for Wales rolled-outWelsh Government lockdown message changed to Stay Local to Keep Wales SafeWalesrsquo chief medical officer, Dr Frank Atherton, said: ldquoSince the start of the pandemic, we have been focused on ensuring people who are at greatest risk are protected from coronavirus.ldquoThe spread of coronavirus is being carefully monitored ndashit gets lower, it is possible those within the shielded group will be able to do more.ldquoIf it gets higher, we may advise those people to stop going outside and to stay at home again.Earlier this week, the Welsh Government announced a change in advice for people who are shielding, based on a review of the evidence by the four UK chief medical officers.From June , everyone who is shielding are being advised they can leave their homes to meet people from another household outdoors, as long as strictly follow to social distancing rules and good hygiene measures. This includes exercising outdoors.The new August shielding date does not affect this updated advice.Dr Atherton said: ldquoWe are asking all those in the shielding group to continue to shield until August  because coronavirus has not gone away.ldquoWe want to do all we can to keep those people in this group safe and that means asking them to continue to shield.ldquoI will continue to work with my chief medical officer colleagues to review the evidence for this group and will write to them again in the summer.Everyone in the shielding group has been asked to continue to rely on their existing support networks ndash including family and friends ndashfor help with everyday tasks, such as food shopping and collecting prescription medicines.For those who do not have anyone locally, the Welsh Government has worked with local authorities and the Wales Council for Voluntary Action , major food retailers, GPs and pharmacies to ensure they can access the support they need to continue shielding.The arrangements for weekly food boxes for those people who are shielding who have no support from family or friends will continue to be in place.The Welsh Government also continues to work with supermarket retailers in Wales which offer online shopping and home delivery to make sure priority slots are available for people who are shielding.Dr Atherton added: ldquoA huge amount of work has been going on to support people who are shielding and Irsquod particularly like to thank local authorities, the WLGA, WCVA and county voluntary councils for their ongoing work and support. story: Members of the Tabernacle Baptist Churchhave been live streaming their brilliant virtual Sunday services via Facebook Live and Youtube, and the services have attracted hundreds of viewers, with some as far as Germany tuning in.More NewsBarry McDonalds drive thru is back in businessPupils in Wales canto school on June , Welsh Government announceBarry Dock and Penarth leboats seventh launch to tide stranded people on Sully IslandStarting on the second week of lockdown at the end of March, the videos have grown in popularity, and church member Jack Westmore says it is ldquosomething good to come out of a tough time.ldquoIt has been a way of bringing some familiar faces to peoplersquos homes every week, and is something for our members to look forward to, said Mr Westmore. ldquoSome are also not members and are generally interested and want to have a Sunday service.ldquoWe are very lucky that we have some brilliant musicians and tech-savvy members who have really stood up to the plate and made this lockdown bearable for so many of us.Church Elder Claire Grafton explained the impact of the virtual services, adding: ldquoWe have two elderly members who tune in, and one isnrsquot as good with the technology as the other, but one holds the screen right up to the other and they sing along. Itrsquos wonderful to see.The services have been so successful that the congregation is considering continuing its virtual services when lockdown is lted.ldquoBefore lockdown we were getting  visitors regularly on a Sunday, so I would assume that can no longer happen, so the virtual services are certainly something we are considering for the long term, said Ms Grafton.ldquoBut we canrsquot wait until we are back to the church and we are putting plans in place to ensure we can do that as soon as possible.To see Tabs Penarths videos, visit their Facebook page at https:www.facebook TabsPenarth  or their Youtube channel at https:www.youtube channel UCMwHmBLFoZkTPgNHZEw. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: world environment day wales can lead charge quest truly green recovery
story: As the world marks World Environment Day , Sir David has underlined NRWrsquos commitment to supporting the Welsh Government to deliver a green recovery that prioritises sustainable economic growth and benefits the climate and our natural environment.He also outlined how Wales must lead the way on a green route out of the covid- crisis and how Walesrsquo response to the lockdown will play a critical role in determining our effectiveness - or otherwise - in responding to the climate and nature emergencies.MORE STORIESPorthkerry Park pond project improves Barry environmentCadoxton Brook flood scheme plans will go on display at Dinas Powys Community LibraryCoastal areas expected to be hit by large wavesSir David said: ldquoThe impact of covid- has brought sharply into focus the importance we place on our local environment ndash particularly when our access to it has been limited to serve a greater purpose.ldquoIt has also made the case for tackling the climate emergency starker than ever before.The pledges NRW made last year to respond to that challenge remain at the heart of everything we do.The concept of a sustainable recovery will only add momentum to our approach to tackling the climate emergency, and deeper instil the commitment needed to succeed.Looking at how a green recovery could effectively be achieved, NRW suggests that an overall package could focus on a recovery that strengthens our local economies by capitalising on the renewed sense of place and connection we now have with our communities and developing active travel measures which will help to safeguard the quality of the air we breathe.NRW also suggests developing support packages for businesses and sectors that have decarbonisation and nature-based solutions at their core and reforming and developing longer-term policy ambitions in areas such as post-Brexit agricultural and land management support, and the approach to developing a more circular economy.Sir David also reiterated the importance of approaching the green recovery as a coalition with one voice.He added: ldquoThis World Environment Day we need everyone in Wales ndash the government, the private, third and tourism sectors, environmental NGOs, the agricultural and recreational sectors and our communities across Wales - to work together to confront this global challenge head on and seize the opportunity to lead the charge for a truly green recovery. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: new app crucial sorting bookings vale glamorgan recycling centre
story: First Minister Mark Drakeford announced last month that recycling centres could reopen as part of the easing of coronavirus restrictions.More than , bookings were made on the first day when they reopened in the Vale of Glamorgan ndash  bookings were made every minute.The Zipporah app called Generic, is helping people in the county to book an appointment. This is proving vital in helping recycling centres manage attendance, maintain physical distancing and reduce queuing.MORE STORIESNew app to provide specialist advice to GPs in secondsNew pound, fund to help digital firms develop technology to combat coronavirusSouth Wales freemasons donate  tablets to hospitalsResidents are also provided with clear instructions and procedures to follow before arriving and during their visit to a recycling centre.The app has also been taken up by local authorities outside Wales. Zipporah is providing it to all free of charge.Economy, Transport and North Wales Minister, Ken Skates said:ldquoThis is a fantastic example of a Welsh company taking action in a time of crisis to introduce a new product for the benefit of public services and local residents.ldquoIndications show the Generic app has already proved a success at recycling centres in the Vale of Glamorgan. This is absolutely essential in ensuring physical distancing rules are maintained and people can come and go with confidence and ease.ldquoIrsquod like to thank Zipporah and the Vale of Glamorgan Council for working collaboratively to bring a successful solution into the public domain.Zipporahrsquos technical director Scott Burton said:"Our appointment solution has already been incredibly effective especially in facilitating the organised re-opening of recycling centres ndash not only in Wales but also across England and Scotland.ldquoAs well as keeping recycling centres running smoothly, Zipporah technology has been crucial in allowing social distancing to be maintained ndash upholding the safety of both the public and staff alike.ldquoWersquore delighted with how successful the system has been in benefiting those using during this challenging period.Deputy Minister for Housing and Local Government, Hannah Blythyn said:ldquoWe have had to adapt our ways of working, since the coronavirus outbreak and it is fantastic to see local authorities and businesses coming together and using innovative technology to ensure key public services are maintained.ldquoEnsuring the safety of staff and the public at recycling centres is vital.The Generic app has not only helped to achieve this but has allowed recycling centres to run smoothly while adopting social distancing. I hope wersquoll see more of this collaborative working in the future as we respond to the pandemic.Vale council cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Peter King said: ldquoWersquore delighted with how smoothly our household waste recycling centres have been able to reopen after a period of closure.ldquoAs anticipated demand for these facilities was extremely high, but thanks to proper planning and the hard work of council staff many potential problems relating to queuing and waiting times have been avoided.ldquoThe implementation of a booking system was crucial to the reopening operation and wersquod like to thank Zipporah for their support.ldquoTheyrsquove provided us with reliable and robust software that has stood up well to signicant pressure.Vale resident, Stuart Evans said: ldquoAfter a couple of months of having a full garden of shelving units, carpet, underlay, I was so grateful to be able to get to the recycling centre in Barry.ldquoTime slots worked perfectly and it felt so lsquonormalrsquo.ldquoStaff were very organised and helpful. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: wales make face masks compulsory public transport
story: Mark Drakeford said Englands decision to bring in a requirement for coverings had raised issues for people commuting between the two countries.It came as Public Health Wales said a further four people had died after testing positive for coronavirus, taking the total number of deaths to ,, while the number of positive cases grew by  to ,.More NewsLuxury car manufacturer Aston Martin to axe  jobsMans efforts toWorld War One Penarth soldiers plaque found in New ZealandPenarth RNLI leboat crew rescues people caught out by Bristol Channel tideOn Friday, Mr Drakeford was questioned about his governments position on non-medical coverings after a trade union representing doctors in Wales said bringing in rules would help control the spread of Covid- and save lives.Mr Drakeford told the Governments daily press briefing in Cardf: "The context for face coverings has changed because of an announcement made yesterday in England about mandatory use of face masks on public transport."That will not come in until June , and that gives us a short number of days in order to consider the position here in Wales recognising that changed context."Mr Drakeford said a "definitive statement" on the issue would be made in the first part of next week, and that detailed questions about Englands new rules would be explored with ministers and officials in Westminster.But he said the UK Government had not discussed or given advanced notice of the decision with Wales, and questioned whether England was concerned with "making the headline, and then worrying about the detail afterwards"."I wish that wed had a chance to explore this with the UK Government before they made the announcements," he said."That would have allowed us to have some answers to the questions that I raised today before the event rather than after the event."But while on the bulk of issues we continue to be able to have discussion and co-operation in advance of decision making, in a small number of cases we hear about it only after the decision has been made."He added: "Were going to have to use the time we now have to find out from them the extent to which they have got answers to these questions in advance of making the decision, or whether its a matter of making the headline, and then worrying about the detail afterwards."Mr Drakeford said the advice from the chief medical officer for Wales remained that wearing face masks gave people "some marginal extra protection" but was not sufficient to make it mandatory."The chief medical officer has expressed his anxieties that people might do more risky things because they think a face mask offers them protection, which it doesnt," Mr Drakeford said."But context changes because in England it is mandatory to use face masks while on public transport."Trains and roads between north and south Wales weave in and out of the border all the time and in a sheer practical sense, we have to think through whether having separate regimes is a possibility when you can leave on a train that starts in Wales, goes into England, comes back into Wales, goes back into England, comes back into Wales."Earlier on Friday the British Medical AssociationWales called on the Welsh Government to change its stance on non-medical face coverings, and ensure a supply are available to the public.The trade unions council chair for Wales, Dr David Bailey, said: "BMA Cymru Wales advocates the wearing of face coverings by the public in areas where they cannot socially distance."There still remains a considerable risk of infection, and emerging evidence has shown thatmouths and noses are covered when people are in areas where they cannot socially distance, it may help in controlling the spread of infection of Covid- and therefore save lives."BMA Cymru Wales is calling on the Welsh Government to change their position immediately, to lessen the risk of the public spreading the virus."Wales main train operator, Transport for Wales, said it would "work collaboratively" with partners to ensure passengers were kept safe travelling across borders.A spokesman said: "The cross-border nature of our network means that we will continue to work collaboratively with industry partners to ensure customers understand how they can travel safely as they travel between Wales and England."The safety of our colleagues and customers is our top priority and wed like to reinforce the message to stay local and only use public transportthe journey is essential and theres no other travel alternative." article_url   content_id   site_id title: south wales detectorists discover treasure nine occasions
story: The British Museum said it was pleasing to see local museums across the country acquiring these "important archaeological objects", but urged treasure hunters to follow the laws surrounding metal detecting.More NewsNew app crucial in sorting bookings at Vale of Glamorgan recycling centreLuxury car manufacturer Aston Martin to axe  jobsPenarth RNLI leboat crew rescues people caught out by Bristol Channel tideIn , there were nine treasure finds reported to Central South Wales Coroners Court, which is responsible for holding treasure inquests.It means a total of  discoveries in the last three years in the area.Across England and Wales, , finds were reported last year ndash  per cent more than the year before.Lincolnshire was the best area for treasure, with  finds last year alone. In contrast, no treasure whatsoever was found in  areas.The Treasure Act, introduced in , defines treasure as discoveries older than  years.These include coins, prehistoric metallic objects and artefacts that are at least  per cent precious metal such as gold or silver.All potential treasure finds are processed by the British Museum, whose experts advise coroners on whether the find fits the definition of treasure.If a coroner rules that it is treasure, both local and national museums are given the chance to acquire the pieces, and the finder will be paid a sum depending on the treasures value.Butthe find is determined not to be treasure, or no museums want it, then it is ed to the treasure hunter.A Ministry of Justice report on last years treasure finds said the number of discoveries has been steadily increasing since the Treasure Act commenced ndash rising from just  finds in .There were  inquests concluded last year, with more than  per cent ing a verdict of treasure.Ian Richardson, treasure registrar at the British Museum, said: "The purpose of the Treasure Act is to enable important archaeological objects to be acquired by museums, for the benefit of all."It is pleasing to see local museums interested in acquiring a number of these findsthey are declared Treasure."Anyone fortunate enough to discover something they think is treasure must report their finding to the coroner within two weeks, so the court can hold an inquest to decide who should get the to keep it.Failure to do so can result in an unlimited fine or up to three months in prison.With metal detecting being permitted again as lockdown lts, Mr Richardson urged people to continue to follow the Code of Practice for Responsible Metal Detecting and report their discoveries, including Treasure. story: People marched to opposed the dam in September " Victory in campaign to save ancient woodland as dam plan is abandonedMill Stream" Skip to next photo Show caption s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA CAMPAIGN to save the ancient woodland of Cwm George and Casehill Woods near Dinas Powys, has resulted in success.National Resources Waleshad proposed constructing a dam m wide and .m high in the meadow at the Woodland Trust site in Dinas Powys.NRW proposed the dam as one option to alleviate potential flood risk.More NewsVale nurse developed coronavirus symptoms after sitting with patient, inquest toldMillions become unpaid carers due to coronavirus crisisPenarth RNLI station marks  years despite current coronavirus lockdownThe campaign by the Save Dinas Powys Woods and Protect Homes from Flooding group was launched in March  after the Woodland Trust said NRW was proposing to build a dam within its site of Cwm George and Casehill Woods.The group said the proposals would involve cutting down  square metres of trees including  square metres of ancient trees and regular flooding upstream during high rainfall would result in further destruction of ancient trees, hedgerows, wildle, and plants.Dormice and other protected species like bats were at risk, the group said.The woods, much-loved by the community, attracts visitors from other areas and is the Woodland Trustrsquos most visited site in Wales with more than , visitors.Hundreds of people took part in marches in  to oppose the dam.NRW released its draft Outline Business Case in February  and a consultation period with the local community took place.Hundreds of people attended a meeting in February to oppose the dam and they wrote to NRW, with their views, during the coronavirus lockdown.Chairman of Save Dinas Powys Woods  Protect Homes From Flooding, Peter Smith said the group welcomed the announcement that NRW will not develop a dam in the Dinas Powys Woods.ldquoLocal people recognise the flood risk in the village, but are overwhelmingly in favour of a natural flood management programmein the Cadoxton River and Eastbrook catchments, plus improved channel maintenance andrequired local hard defences, rather than an environmentally unfriendly dam, Dr Smith said.ldquoOur proposals will slow the flow of the rivers upstream thus reducing the risk of flash flooding, and by removing obstacles improve flow downstream.ldquoWe now look forward to working with NRW and The Woodland Trust to design an effective NFM scheme.ldquoBoth have expertise in this area, and, having made funds available for NFM projects, we know that the Welsh Government is keen for Wales to become an exemplar of good practice. community involvement and support will remain key features of our campaign.He added: ldquoWe are grateful to people far and wide who have supported our campaign, including the Woodland Trust, our local community councils, and county councillors.ldquoWe extend our particular thanks our local MS, Jane Hutt, for her advocacy and support.Community councillor, Chris Franks said NRW must not now ignore any problems.ldquoClearly over the years there has been reduced spending on maintenance of the stream through Dinas Powys and towards Barry, he said.ldquoThe public has said that the NRW must improve monitoring of flows on the Cadoxton River, implement natural flood management measures and improve flow at Cardf Road bridge where the stream passes under the A to reduce flood risk.Vale MS Jane Hutt said: ldquolsquoFollowing our meeting on May  Sir David Henshaw chairman of NRW wrote to me on May  to say that NRW received almost  responses to our consultation on the Outline Business Case with the vast majority being opposed to the upstream storage option on the Cadoxton Brook.NRW chairman, Sir Henshaw said: ldquoWhen we consider the marginal case for this option, it is therefore clear that we will not be pursuing an upstream storage scheme. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey Organisationand recommending people in Wales wear three-layer face coverings in situations where social distancing is not possible.The evidence remains clear that maintaining a two-metre distance and good hand hygiene is the most effective way to protect yourself and others from contracting coronavirus.But updated guidance from the WHO said three layer face coverings could help provide some control of the virus in specic circumstances.This updated advice only applies to people who are not showing symptoms of coronavirus.People who are symptomatic must self-isolate for seven days and get a test, as set out in existing guidance.Unless the test shows a negative result, they must not go out during this time, even with a face covering or mask.MORE STORIESWelsh Government lockdown message changed to Stay Local to Keep Wales SafeContact tracing system for Wales rolled outShielding to continue for , people in WalesHealth minister, Vaughan Gething said: ldquoWashing your hands, avoiding touching your face and maintaining a two-metre distance from others remain the best way of stopping the spread of the virus.ldquoOn Friday , the WHO updated their guidance on face coverings, advising that they should be considered in settings where maintaining social distancing is dficult."However, to be crystal clear, wearing a face covering does not replace the need for social distancing or washing your hands regularly.ldquoFurther scientic evidence is needed on the benefits to the wider public of wearing face coverings, but observational findings so far suggest that homemade or purchased three-layer face-coverings might reduce transmission from one person to anothermade, worn, handled and disposed of properly.ldquoTherefore, on balance, we are recommending to the people of Wales that three-layer face-coverings should be used in situations where social distancing measures can be more dficult to achieve, for example, on public transport."We are not recommending their use outdoors.ldquoThe wearing of face coverings will not be mandatory, but we will encourage people to do this for the benefit of themselves and others.Mr Gething stressed that this advice only applies to people who are not showing symptoms of coronavirus, adding: ldquoAnyone who has a high temperature, a new, continuous cough or a loss or change to their sense of smell or taste must self-isolate for a minimum of seven days and get a test as quickly as possible. title: irish government writes uk counterparts daniel kinahan controversy
story: British boxer Tyson Fury thanked UAE-based Daniel Kinahan for reaching an agreement for him to fight Anthony Joshua next year.On Wednesday, Fury said he was responsible for organising ldquothe biggest fight in British boxing history.The High Court in Dublin previously named Kinahan as a senior figure in an organised crime gang involved in international drug trafficking operations and firearm offences.Irish Sport Minister Brendan Grfin said he had asked department officials to draft a letter to his UK counterpart about ldquoour outrage about a ldquocompletely unacceptable situation.He said: ldquoMy heart goes out to the decent volunteers and participants in boxing around the country who give so much time and effort to their communities.Irelandrsquos Department of Foreign Affairs has contacted authorities in the United Arab Emirates regarding the controversy surrounding Mr Kinahan, Taoiseach Leo Varadkar has confirmed.He told the Dail on Thursday: ldquoI was taken aback by Tyson Fury and his video and dropping in that name you mentioned.He said Kinahan has a ldquochequered history in the state.Mr Varadkar added: ldquoWhile I cannot comment on any particular garda operation, I can certainly assure you that there has been contact between the Department of Foreign Affairs and the authorities in the United Arab Emirates about that matter.He made the comments in response to Labour leader Alan Kelly, who called for the Irish Government to intervene in the controversy.Mr Kelly said: ldquoThere is an inidual from our country who is, according to the High Court, a very senior figure in organised crime on a global scale.ldquoAccording to CAB , he has controlled and managed operations of the Kinahan organised crime group for some time.ldquoHe has now rebranded himself in the Middle East as a boxing promoter and one of the most famous iniduals involved in that has described him as a lsquosmart, able and honest manrsquo.Itrsquos official title: slave traders name removed tower block statues set go london
story: It comes as the Guyrsquos and St Thomasrsquo hospitals in London announced it will remove two statues of their namesakes from public view due to their links to the slave trade.A video circulating online on Thursday evening shows men in hard hats scaling Colston Tower in Bristol city centre and removing the controversial figurersquos name from atop the high-rise building. vw,vw,px, px"Edward Colstonrsquos name was removed from Colston Tower in Bristol The -storey tower block, in Colston Street, accommodates a number of offices.Hours earlier, Colstonrsquos statue was fished out of Bristol harbour after being pulled down and dumped into the water during an anti-racism demonstration on Sunday.The toppling of Colstonrsquos statue acted as a catalyst for more monuments linked with Britainrsquos colonial past to be taken down.The latest to follow suit is Guyrsquos and St Thomasrsquo NHS Foundation Trust, after it confirmed two figures depicting Robert Clayton and Thomas Guy will be taken out of public view due to their association with the slave trade. vw,vw,px, px"St Thomasrsquo Hospital in Central London Clayton, a former Lord Mayor of London, had ties to the Royal African Company, which transported slaves to the Americas, while Guy invested in the South Sea Company, which was also involved in the trade.Guyrsquos and St Thomasrsquo NHS Foundation Trust said in a statement: ldquoLike many organisations in Britain, we know that we have a duty to address the legacy of colonialism, racism and slavery in our work.ldquoWe absolutely recognise the public hurt and anger that is generated by the symbolism of public statues of historical figures associated with the slave trade in some way.ldquoWe have therefore decided to remove statues of Robert Clayton and Thomas Guy from public view, and we look forward to engaging with and receiving guidance from the Mayor of Londonrsquos commission on each.ldquoWe see the pervasive and harmful effects of structural racism every day through our work ndash black people have worse health outcomes, and this inequality is one of many ways racism permeates our society.Meanwhile, Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole Council has delayed plans to temporarily remove a statue of Scouts founder Robert Baden-Powell after angry residents vowed to fight to protect it.The council had originally said it would move the statue from Poole Quay on Thursday over concerns it was on a target list compiled by anti-racism activists.Campaigners have focused in on Lord Baden-Powell due to his associations with the Nazis and the Hitler Youth programme, as well as his actions in the military.The statue features on a ldquotopple the racists website which lists more than  statues and memorials across the UK which they argue should be taken down, because they ldquocelebrate slavery and racism.In a statement issued on Thursday afternoon, the council said the listing ldquoplaced the much-loved statue at risk of damage or even destruction.It added: ldquoWe know that local people feel proud of Lord Baden-Powellrsquos and the Scout movementrsquos links with Poole, and that some people feel that we would be giving in to the protesters by temporarily removing the statue.ldquoHowever, we feel it is responsible to protect it for future generations to enjoy and respect.The council said the statue would not be removed because its ldquofoundations are deeper than originally envisaged with discussions needed with contractors on how to move it safely.-hour security will be put in place ldquountil it is either removed or the threat diminishes, the council said.It added: ldquoShould the statue be removed temporarily, barring unforeseen circumstances we willit to the Quay as soon as the threat level subsides. vw,vw,px, px"Rover Scouts Chris Arthurand Matthew Trott travelled from Cwmbran, Wales, to express support for the statue of Robert Baden-Powell on Poole Quay in Dorset Residents gathering around the statue on Thursday vowed to halt its removal, while local Conservative MPs took to Twitter to condemn the plans.Len Banister, , a former Scout, said of the Baden-Powell statue: ldquoHe is the reason I am still here, the pleasure he gives to so many people, they shouldnrsquot take it down, I will fight them off.Rover Scouts Matthew Trott and Christopher Arthur travelled from Cwmbran, Wales, roughly  miles drive away, to express their support for the statue they felt needed protection.Mr Trott, , said: ldquoIrsquod rather see the statue placed in a box in a warehouse for the moment rather than at the bottom of the harbour.ldquoThere have been vicious rumours of Baden-Powell but they are not true at all. He started the foundation I love, I have been a Scout my whole le since I was six, Scouting is my whole le so he is my hero.BADEN-POWELL statue removal:A wider overdue national debate has begun about who we were, who we are  where we should go. Few historical figures comply with st C values. Simply expunging past connections from sight wonrsquot correct wrongs or help us better learn from our past. pic HHfAKSoobFmdash Tobias Ellwood MPJune , Writing on Twitter, Tobias Ellwood, MP for Bournemouth East and former scout, tweeted about the Baden-Powell statue: ldquoA wider overdue national debate has begun about who we were, who we are and where we should go.ldquoFew historical figures comply with st C values. Simply expunging past connections from sight wonrsquot correct wrongs or help us better learn from our past.Mark Howell, the local authorityrsquos deputy leader, had said the statue would only be removed to protect it, with the aim of it permanently remaining in its position overlooking Brownsea Island where Lord Baden-Powell held his first experimental camp in .Council leader Vikki Slade initially claimed on Twitter the decision to remove the statue was on police advice following a ldquothreat, adding: ldquoItrsquos literally less than m from the sea so is at huge risk.Dorset Police later confirmed it had informed the council that the statue was a ldquopotential target, but ldquono advice was given to remove it.The row over the statue comes as authorities across the country face pressure to review contentious monuments following protests over the death of George Floyd and racial injustice.MrFloyddied after a white police officer held him down by pressing his knee into his neck for almost nine minutes in Minneapolis on May .Campaigners have targeted tributes to th century slave owner Sir Thomas Picton, th century colonialist trader Robert Clive and th century merchant Elihu Yale who had links to the slave trade.Memorials to Sir Robert Peel, founder of the Met Police in London have also been challenged, while in the past week graffiti has been left on statues of Queen Victoria in Leeds and Winston Churchill in London.On Tuesday evening, a statue of slave owner Robert Milligan in Londonrsquos Docklands was removed following local authority approval.Baroness Valerie Amos, director of the School of Oriental and African Studiesin London, said on Thursday that a statue of colonialist Cecil Rhodes should be taken down from Oriel College at the University of Oxford.The statue has been the focus of a long-running campaign demanding its removal.Meanwhile, the great-great-grandson of William Gladstone has suggested the th century prime minister would not have stood in the waythere was ldquodemocratic will to remove statues of him.Charlie Gladstone made the comments after online petitions called for Gladstonersquos Library in Hawarden, North Wales, to
